889900_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	We own and operate one of the largest fleets of land-based drilling rigs in the United States.
889900_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	The Company was formed in 1978 and reincorporated in 1993 as a Delaware corporation.
889900_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	Our contract drilling business operates primarily in Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Colorado, Utah, Wyoming, Montana, North Dakota, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and western Canada.
889900_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	As of December 31, 2010, we had a drilling fleet that consisted of 356 marketable land-based drilling rigs.
889900_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	A drilling rig includes the structure, power source and machinery necessary to cause a drill bit to penetrate the earth to a depth desired by the customer.
889900_11_ITEM1_P5_S1	A drilling rig is considered marketable at a point in time if it is operating or can be made ready to operate without significant capital expenditures.
889900_11_ITEM1_P5_S2	We also have a substantial inventory of drill pipe and drilling rig components.
889900_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	We provide pressure pumping services to oil and natural gas operators primarily in Texas and the Appalachian Basin.
889900_11_ITEM1_P6_S1	Pressure pumping services consist primarily of well stimulation and cementing for completion of new wells and remedial work on existing wells.
889900_11_ITEM1_P6_S2	We also own and invest in oil and natural gas assets as a working interest owner.
889900_11_ITEM1_P6_S3	Our oil and natural gas working interests are located primarily in Texas and New Mexico.
889900_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	Prior to January 20, 2010, we provided drilling fluids, completion fluids and related services to oil and natural gas operators offshore in the Gulf of Mexico and on land in Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Louisiana.
889900_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	We sold our drilling and completion fluids services business on January 20, 2010.
889900_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	On October 1, 2010 we acquired the assets and operations of a pressure pumping business and an electric wireline business.
889900_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	The electric wireline business that we acquired was classified as held for sale at December 31, 2010 and sold on January 27, 2011.
889900_11_ITEM1_P8_S2	The results of our drilling and completion fluids services business and our electric wireline business are presented as discontinued operations in this Report.
889900_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	Our revenues, operating profits and identifiable assets are primarily attributable to three industry segments:
889900_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	oil and natural gas exploration and production.
889900_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	All of our industry segments had operating profits in 2010 and 2008.
889900_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	In 2009, our pressure pumping services and oil and natural gas exploration and production segments had operating profits and our contract drilling services segment had an operating loss.
889900_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	See Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and Note 15 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included as a part of Items 7 and 8, respectively, of this Report for financial information pertaining to these industry segments.
889900_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	General We market our contract drilling services to major and independent oil and natural gas operators.
889900_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	As of December 31, 2010, we had 356 marketable land-based drilling rigs based in the following regions:
889900_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	Our marketable drilling rigs have rated maximum depth capabilities ranging from 5,000 feet to 25,000 feet.
889900_11_ITEM1_P14_S1	Of these drilling rigs, 124 are electric rigs and 232 are mechanical rigs.
889900_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	An electric rig differs from a mechanical rig in that the electric rig converts the diesel power (the sole energy source for a mechanical rig) into electricity to power the rig.
889900_11_ITEM1_P15_S1	We also have a substantial inventory of drill pipe and drilling rig components, which may be used in the activation of additional drilling rigs or as replacement parts for marketable rigs.
889900_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	Drilling rigs are typically equipped with engines, drawworks, masts, pumps to circulate the drilling fluid, blowout preventers, drill pipe and other related equipment.
889900_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	Over time, components on a drilling rig are replaced or rebuilt.
889900_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	We spend significant funds each year as part of a program to modify, upgrade and maintain our drilling rigs to ensure that our drilling equipment is competitive.
889900_11_ITEM1_P17_S2	We have spent $1.4 billion during the last three years on capital expenditures to (1) build new land drilling rigs, and (2) modify, upgrade and maintain our drilling fleet.
889900_11_ITEM1_P17_S3	During fiscal years 2010, 2009 and 2008, we spent approximately $656 million, $395 million and $361 million, respectively, on these capital expenditures.
889900_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	Depth and complexity of the well and drill site conditions are the principal factors in determining the specifications of the rig selected for a particular job.
889900_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	Our contract drilling operations depend on the availability of drill pipe, drill bits, replacement parts and other related rig equipment, fuel and qualified personnel.
889900_11_ITEM1_P19_S1	Some of these have been in short supply from time to time.
889900_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	Drilling Contracts Most of our drilling contracts are with established customers on a competitive bid or negotiated basis.
889900_11_ITEM1_P20_S1	Our drilling contracts are either on a well-to-well basis or a term basis.
889900_11_ITEM1_P20_S2	Well-to-well contracts are generally short-term in nature and cover the drilling of a single well or a series of wells.
889900_11_ITEM1_P20_S3	Term contracts are entered into for a specified period of time (frequently one to three years) and provide for the use of the drilling rig to drill multiple wells.
889900_11_ITEM1_P20_S4	During 2010, our average number of days to drill a well (which includes moving to the drill site, rigging up and rigging down) was approximately 21 days.
889900_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	Our drilling contracts obligate us to provide and operate a drilling rig and to pay certain operating expenses, including wages of drilling personnel and necessary maintenance expenses.
889900_11_ITEM1_P21_S1	Most drilling contracts are subject to termination by the customer on short notice and may or may not contain provisions for the payment of an early termination fee to us in the event that the contract is terminated by the customer.
889900_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	Generally, we indemnify our customers against claims by our employees and claims that might arise from surface pollution caused by spills of fuel, lubricants and other solvents within our control.
889900_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	Generally, the customers indemnify us against claims that might arise from other surface and subsurface pollution.
889900_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	Each drilling contract contains the actual terms setting forth our rights and obligations and those of the customer, any of which rights and obligations may deviate from what is customary due to industry conditions or other factors.
889900_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	Our drilling contracts provide for payment on a daywork, footage or turnkey basis, or a combination thereof.
889900_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	In each case, we provide the rig and crews.
889900_11_ITEM1_P24_S2	Our bid for each job depends upon location, depth and anticipated complexity of the well, on-site drilling conditions, equipment to be used, estimated risks involved, estimated duration of the job, availability of drilling rigs and other factors particular to each proposed well.
889900_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	Under daywork contracts, we provide the drilling rig and crew to the customer.
889900_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	The customer supervises the drilling of the well.
889900_11_ITEM1_P25_S2	Our compensation is based on a contracted rate per day during the period the drilling rig is utilized.
889900_11_ITEM1_P25_S3	We often receive a lower rate when the drilling rig is moving or when drilling operations are interrupted or restricted by adverse weather conditions or other conditions beyond our control.
889900_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	Daywork contracts typically provide separately for mobilization of the drilling rig.
889900_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	Except for two wells drilled under footage contracts in 2009, all of the wells we drilled in 2010, 2009 and 2008 were under daywork contracts.
889900_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	Under footage contracts, we contract to drill a well to a certain depth under specified conditions for a fixed price per foot.
889900_11_ITEM1_P27_S1	The customer provides drilling fluids, casing, cementing and well design expertise.
889900_11_ITEM1_P27_S2	These contracts require us to bear the cost of services and supplies that we provide until the well has been drilled to the agreed-upon depth.
889900_11_ITEM1_P27_S3	If we drill the well in less time than estimated, we have the opportunity to improve our profits over those that would be attainable under a daywork contract.
889900_11_ITEM1_P27_S4	Profits are reduced and losses may be incurred if the well requires more days to drill to the contracted depth than estimated.
889900_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	Footage contracts generally contain greater risks for a drilling contractor than daywork contracts.
889900_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	certain risks associated with loss of the well from fire, blowouts and other risks.
889900_11_ITEM1_P29_S1	We drilled two wells under footage contracts in 2009, and we did not drill any wells under footage contracts in 2010 or 2008.
889900_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	Under turnkey contracts, we contract to drill a well to a certain depth under specified conditions for a fixed fee.
889900_11_ITEM1_P30_S1	In a turnkey arrangement, we are required to bear the costs of services, supplies and equipment beyond those typically provided under a footage contract.
889900_11_ITEM1_P30_S2	In addition to the drilling rig and crew, we are required to provide the drilling and completion fluids, casing, cementing, and the technical well design and engineering services during the drilling process.
889900_11_ITEM1_P30_S3	We also typically assume certain risks associated with drilling the well such as fires, blowouts, cratering of the well bore and other such risks.
889900_11_ITEM1_P30_S4	Compensation occurs only when the agreed- upon scope of the work has been completed, which requires us to make larger up-front working capital commitments prior to receiving payments under a turnkey drilling contract.
889900_11_ITEM1_P30_S5	Under a turnkey contract, we have the opportunity to improve our profits if the drilling process goes as expected and there are no complications or time delays.
889900_11_ITEM1_P30_S6	Given the increased exposure we have under a turnkey contract, however, profits can be significantly reduced and losses can be incurred if complications or delays occur during the drilling process.
889900_11_ITEM1_P30_S7	Turnkey contracts generally involve the highest degree of risk among the three different types of drilling contracts.
889900_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	Although we have entered into turnkey contracts in the past, we did not enter into any turnkey contracts in the past three years.
889900_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	Contract Drilling Activity Information regarding our contract drilling activity for the last three years follows:
889900_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	A rig is considered to be operating if it is earning revenue pursuant to a contract on a given day.
889900_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	Includes standby days under term contracts where revenue was earned but the rig was not working.
889900_11_ITEM1_P34_S1	The number of these standby days under term contracts was zero in 2010, 2,070 in 2009 and 486 in 2008.
889900_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	Drilling Rigs and Related Equipment We estimate the depth capacity with respect to our marketable rigs as of December 31, 2010 to be as follows:
889900_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	At December 31, 2010, we owned and operated 317 trucks and 402 trailers used to rig down, transport and rig up our drilling rigs.
889900_11_ITEM1_P36_S1	Our ownership of trucks and trailers reduces our dependency upon third parties for these services and generally enhances the efficiency of our contract drilling operations, particularly in periods of high drilling rig utilization.
889900_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	Most repair and overhaul work to our drilling rig equipment is performed at our yard facilities located in Texas, Oklahoma, Wyoming, Utah, Pennsylvania and western Canada.
889900_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	General We provide pressure pumping services to oil and natural gas operators primarily in Texas and the Appalachian Basin.
889900_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	Pressure pumping services consist of well stimulation and cementing for the completion of new wells and remedial work on existing wells.
889900_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	well stimulation through fracturing to allow the flow of oil and natural gas.
889900_11_ITEM1_P40_S1	This is accomplished by pumping fluids under pressure into the well bore to fracture the formation.
889900_11_ITEM1_P40_S2	Many wells in conventional plays also receive well stimulation services.
889900_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	The cementing process inserts material between the wall of the well bore and the casing to support and stabilize the casing.
889900_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	Equipment Our pressure pumping equipment at December 31, 2010 includes equipment used in providing hydraulic and nitrogen fracturing services as well as nitrogen, cementing and acid pumping services as follows:
889900_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	Our pressure pumping operations are supported by a fleet of equipment including blenders, tractors, manifold trailers and numerous trailers for transportation of materials to and from the worksite as well as bins for storage of materials at the worksite.
889900_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	We own and invest in oil and natural gas assets as a working interest owner.
889900_11_ITEM1_P44_S1	Our oil and natural gas working interests are located primarily in producing regions of Texas and New Mexico.
889900_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	The customers of each of our contract drilling and pressure pumping business segments are oil and natural gas operators.
889900_11_ITEM1_P45_S1	Our customer base includes both major and independent oil and natural gas operators.
889900_11_ITEM1_P45_S2	During 2010, no single customer accounted for 10% or more of our consolidated operating revenues.
889900_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	Our contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses are highly competitive.
889900_11_ITEM1_P46_S1	Historically, available equipment used in these businesses has frequently exceeded demand in our markets.
889900_11_ITEM1_P46_S2	The price for our services is a key competitive factor in our markets, in part because equipment used in our businesses can be moved from one area to another in response to market conditions.
889900_11_ITEM1_P46_S3	In addition to price, we believe availability and condition of equipment, quality of personnel, service quality and safety record are key factors in determining which contractor is awarded a job in the markets in which we operate.
889900_11_ITEM1_P46_S4	We expect that the market for land drilling and pressure pumping services will continue to be highly competitive.

889900_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	We believe we use operating and disposal practices that are standard in the industry.
889900_11_ITEM1_P51_S1	However, hydrocarbons and other materials may have been disposed of, or released in or under properties currently or formerly owned or operated by us or our predecessors, which may have resulted, or may result, in soil and groundwater contamination in certain locations.
889900_11_ITEM1_P51_S2	Any contamination found on, under or originating from the properties may be subject to remediation requirements under Federal, state, foreign and local laws and regulations.
889900_11_ITEM1_P51_S3	In addition, some of these properties have been operated by third parties over whom we have no control of their treatment of hydrocarbon and other materials or the manner in which they may have disposed of or released such materials.
889900_11_ITEM1_P51_S4	We could be required to remove or remediate wastes disposed of or released by prior owners or operators.
889900_11_ITEM1_P51_S5	In addition, it is possible we could be held responsible for oil and natural gas properties in which we own an interest but are not the operator.
889900_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	Some of the environmental laws and regulations that are applicable to our business operations are discussed in the following paragraphs, but the discussion does not cover all environmental laws and regulations that govern our operations.
889900_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	In the United States, the Federal Comprehensive Environmental Response Compensation and Liability Act of 1980, as amended, commonly known as CERCLA, and comparable state statutes impose strict liability on:
889900_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	persons who disposed of or arranged for the disposal of hazardous substances found at sites.
889900_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	The Federal Resource Conservation and Recovery Act ( RCRA ), as amended, and comparable state statutes govern the disposal of hazardous wastes.
889900_11_ITEM1_P55_S1	Although CERCLA currently excludes petroleum from the definition of hazardous substances, and RCRA also excludes certain classes of exploration and production wastes from regulation, such exemptions by Congress under both CERCLA and RCRA may be deleted, limited, or modified in the future.
889900_11_ITEM1_P55_S2	If such changes are made to CERCLA and/or RCRA, we could be required to remove and remediate previously disposed of materials (including materials disposed of or released by prior owners or operators) from properties (including ground water contaminated with hydrocarbons) and to perform removal or remedial actions to prevent future contamination.
889900_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	The Federal Water Pollution Control Act and the Oil Pollution Act of 1990, as amended, and implementing regulations govern:
889900_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	The Oil Pollution Act imposes strict liability for a comprehensive and expansive list of damages from an oil spill into waters from facilities.
889900_11_ITEM1_P57_S1	Liability may be imposed for oil removal costs and a variety of public and private damages.
889900_11_ITEM1_P57_S2	Penalties may also be imposed for violation of Federal safety, construction and operating regulations, and for failure to report a spill or to cooperate fully in a clean-up.
889900_11_ITEM1_P58_S0	The Oil Pollution Act also expands the authority and capability of the Federal government to direct and manage oil spill clean-up and operations, and requires operators to prepare oil spill response plans in cases where it can reasonably be expected that substantial harm will be done to the environment by discharges on or into navigable waters.
889900_11_ITEM1_P59_S0	Failure to comply with ongoing requirements or inadequate cooperation during a spill event may subject a responsible party, such as us, to civil or criminal actions.
889900_11_ITEM1_P60_S0	under the Federal Water Pollution Act, the damages recoverable under the Oil Pollution Act are potentially much greater and can include natural resource damages.
889900_11_ITEM1_P61_S0	Our activities include the performance of hydraulic fracturing services to enhance the production of oil and natural gas from formations with low permeability, such as shales.
889900_11_ITEM1_P62_S0	Due to concerns raised relating to potential impacts of hydraulic fracturing on groundwater quality, legislative and regulatory efforts at the Federal level and in some states have been initiated to render permitting and compliance requirements more stringent for hydraulic fracturing or prohibit the activity altogether.
889900_11_ITEM1_P62_S1	Such efforts could have an adverse effect on oil and natural gas production activities, which in turn could have an adverse effect on the hydraulic fracturing services that we render for our exploration and production customers.
889900_11_ITEM1_P63_S0	In Canada, a variety of Canadian federal, provincial and municipal laws and regulations impose, among other things, restrictions, liabilities and obligations in connection with the generation, handling, use, storage, transportation, treatment and disposal of hazardous substances and wastes and in connection with spills, releases and emissions of various substances to the environment.
889900_11_ITEM1_P63_S1	These laws and regulations also require that facility sites and other properties associated with our operations be operated, maintained, abandoned and reclaimed to the satisfaction of applicable regulatory authorities.
889900_11_ITEM1_P63_S2	In addition, new projects or changes to existing projects may require the submission and approval of environmental assessments or permit applications.
889900_11_ITEM1_P63_S3	These laws and regulations are subject to frequent change, and the clear trend is to place increasingly stringent limitations on activities that may affect the environment.
889900_11_ITEM1_P64_S0	Our operations are also subject to Federal, state, foreign and local laws, rules and regulations for the control of air emissions, including the Federal Clean Air Act and the Canadian Environmental Protection Act.
889900_11_ITEM1_P64_S1	We are aware of the increasing focus of local, state, national and international regulatory bodies on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and climate change issues.
889900_11_ITEM1_P64_S2	We are also aware of legislation proposed by United States lawmakers and the Canadian legislature to reduce GHG emissions, as well as GHG emissions regulations enacted by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the Canadian provinces of Alberta and British Columbia.
889900_11_ITEM1_P64_S3	We will continue to monitor and assess any new policies, legislation or regulations in the areas where we operate to determine the impact of GHG emissions and climate change on our operations and take appropriate actions, where necessary.
889900_11_ITEM1_P64_S4	Any direct and indirect costs of meeting these requirements may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.

889900_11_ITEM1_P66_S0	These and other hazards could cause:
889900_11_ITEM1_P67_S0	serious damage or destruction of the equipment involved and, in addition to environmental damage, could cause substantial damage to producing formations and surrounding areas.
889900_11_ITEM1_P68_S0	Damage to the environment, including property contamination in the form of either soil or ground water contamination, could also result from our operations, including through:
889900_11_ITEM1_P69_S0	We maintain insurance coverage of types and amounts that we believe to be customary in the industry, but we are not fully insured against all risks, either because insurance is not available or because of the high premium costs.
889900_11_ITEM1_P69_S1	Such risks include personal injury, well disasters, extensive fire damage, damage to the environment, and other hazards.
889900_11_ITEM1_P69_S2	The insurance coverage that we maintain includes insurance for fire, windstorm and other risks of physical loss to our rigs and other assets, employer s liability, automobile liability, commercial general liability insurance, and workers compensation insurance.
889900_11_ITEM1_P69_S3	We cannot assure, however, that any insurance obtained by us will be adequate to cover any losses or liabilities, or that this insurance will continue to be available or available on terms that are acceptable to us.
889900_11_ITEM1_P69_S4	While we carry insurance to cover physical damage to, or loss of, our drilling rigs and other assets, such insurance does not cover the full replacement cost of the rigs or other assets, and we do not carry insurance against loss of earnings resulting from such damage.
889900_11_ITEM1_P69_S5	Liabilities for which we are not insured, or which exceed the policy limits of our applicable insurance, could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
889900_11_ITEM1_P70_S0	In addition to insurance coverage, we also attempt to obtain indemnification from our customers for certain risks.
889900_11_ITEM1_P70_S1	These indemnity agreements typically require our customers to hold us harmless in the event of loss of production or reservoir damage.
889900_11_ITEM1_P70_S2	There is no assurance that we will obtain such contractual indemnity, and if obtained, whether such indemnity will be enforceable, whether the customer will be able to satisfy such indemnity or whether such indemnity will be supported by adequate insurance maintained by the customer.

889900_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Global Economic Conditions May Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Beginning in late 2008 and continuing through 2009, there was a substantial deterioration in the global economic environment.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	As part of this deterioration, there was substantial uncertainty in the capital markets and access to financing was reduced.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Due to these conditions, our customers reduced or curtailed their drilling programs, which resulted in a decrease in demand for our services.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P2_S3	Furthermore, these factors resulted in certain of our customers experiencing an inability to pay suppliers, including us.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Although the significant deterioration in the global economic environment appeared to stabilize to some degree during 2010, there is no assurance that the global economic environment could not quickly deteriorate again due to one or more factors.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P3_S1	A return of the conditions causing a deterioration in the global economic environment could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We are Dependent on the Oil and Natural Gas Industry and Market Prices for Oil and Natural Gas.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Declines in Oil and Natural Gas Prices Have Adversely Affected Our Operating Results.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Our revenue, profitability and cash flows are highly dependent upon prevailing prices for natural gas and oil.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	For many years, oil and natural gas prices and markets have been extremely volatile.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	the ability of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, commonly known as OPEC, to set and maintain production and price targets.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	All of these factors are beyond our control.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	During 2008, the monthly average market price of natural gas (monthly average Henry Hub price as reported by the Energy Information Administration) peaked in June at $13.06 per Mcf before rapidly declining to an average of $5.99 per Mcf in December.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P9_S1	In 2009, the monthly average market price of natural gas declined further to a low of $3.06 per Mcf in September.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P9_S2	The monthly average market price of natural gas has not recovered to levels experienced during early 2008 and was $4.38 per Mcf in December 2010.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P9_S3	This volatility and the extended declines in the market price of natural gas resulted in our customers significantly reducing their drilling activities beginning in the fourth quarter of 2008, and drilling activities remained low through 2009 before increasing somewhat in 2010.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P9_S4	The increase in 2010 can be attributed partially to increased activity in oil rich basins as a result of the growing development of unconventional oil reservoirs and an improvement in the price of oil compared to 2009.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P9_S5	Although our average number of rigs operating increased during 2010, it remains well below the number of our available rigs.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P9_S6	Construction of new land drilling rigs in the United States during the last ten years has significantly contributed to excess capacity.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P9_S7	As a result of decreased drilling activity and excess capacity, our average number of rigs operating has declined significantly from historic highs.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P9_S8	We expect oil and natural gas prices to continue to be volatile and to affect our financial condition, operations and ability to access sources of capital.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P9_S9	Low market prices for natural gas and oil would likely result in low demand for our drilling rigs and pressure pumping services and would adversely affect our operating results, financial condition and cash flows.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	A General Excess of Operable Land Drilling Rigs, Increasing Rig Specialization and Excess Pressure Pumping Equipment May Adversely Affect Our Utilization and Profit Margins.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The North American land drilling industry has experienced periods of downturn in demand over the last decade.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P11_S1	During these periods, there have been substantially more drilling rigs available than necessary to meet demand.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P11_S2	As a result, drilling contractors have had difficulty sustaining profit margins and, at times, have sustained losses during the downturn periods.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	In addition, unconventional resource plays have substantially increased recently and some drilling rigs are not capable of drilling these wells efficiently.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Accordingly, the utilization of some older technology drilling rigs may be hampered by their lack of capability to successfully compete for this work.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Other ongoing factors which could continue to adversely affect utilization rates and pricing, even in an environment of high oil and natural gas prices and increased drilling activity, include:
889900_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Construction of new drilling rigs increased significantly during the last ten years.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P13_S1	The addition of new drilling rigs to the market and the recent decrease in demand has resulted in excess capacity.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P13_S2	Similarly, the substantial recent increase in unconventional resource plays has led to higher demand for pressure pumping services.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P13_S3	As a result, we believe there has been, and we expect there to continue to be, a significant increase in the construction of new pressure pumping equipment.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P13_S4	The addition of new pressure pumping equipment, as well as any general decline in demand for pressure pumping services, could result in there being substantially more pressure pumping equipment available than necessary to meet demand.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P13_S5	If this were to occur, providers of pressure pumping services will have difficulty sustaining profit margins and may sustain losses during downturn periods.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	future level of demand for our contract drilling or pressure pumping services or future conditions in the oil and natural gas contract drilling or pressure pumping businesses.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Shortages of Drill Pipe, Replacement Parts, Other Equipment and Materials Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	During periods of increased demand for drilling and pressure pumping services, the industry has experienced shortages of drill pipe, replacement parts, other equipment and materials, including proppants and gels for our pressure pumping operations.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P16_S1	These shortages can cause the price of these items to increase significantly and require that orders for the items be placed well in advance of expected use.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P16_S2	In addition, any interruption in supply due to vendor or other issues could result in significant delays in delivery of equipment and materials or prevent operations.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P16_S3	These price increases and delays in delivery may require us to increase capital and repair expenditures and incur higher operating costs.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P16_S4	Severe shortages or delays in delivery could limit our ability to operate our drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	The Oil Service Business Segments in Which We Operate Are Highly Competitive with Excess Capacity, which Adversely Affects Our Operating Results.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Our land drilling and pressure pumping businesses are highly competitive.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P18_S1	At times, available land drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment exceed the demand for such equipment.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P18_S2	This excess capacity has resulted in substantial competition for drilling and pressure pumping contracts.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P18_S3	The fact that drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment are mobile and can be moved from one market to another in response to market conditions heightens the competition in the industry.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We believe that price competition for drilling and pressure pumping contracts will continue due to the existence of available rigs and pressure pumping equipment.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	In recent years, many drilling and pressure pumping companies have consolidated or merged with other companies.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Although this consolidation has decreased the total number of competitors, we believe the competition for drilling and pressure pumping services will continue to be intense.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Labor Shortages and Rising Labor Costs Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	During periods of increasing demand for contract drilling and pressure pumping services, the industry experiences shortages of qualified personnel.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P22_S1	During these periods, our ability to attract and retain sufficient qualified personnel to market and operate our drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment is adversely affected, which negatively impacts both our operations and profitability.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P22_S2	Operationally, it is more difficult to hire qualified personnel, which adversely affects our ability to mobilize inactive rigs and pressure pumping equipment in response to the increased demand for such services.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P22_S3	Additionally, wage rates for drilling and pressure pumping personnel are likely to increase during periods of increasing demand, resulting in higher operating costs.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Growth Through the Building of New Rigs and Pressure Pumping Equipment and Rig and Other Acquisitions are Not Assured.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	We have increased our drilling rig fleet and pressure pumping horsepower in the past through mergers, acquisitions and new construction.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P24_S1	The land drilling and pressure pumping industries have experienced significant consolidation, and there can be no assurance that acquisition opportunities will be available in the future.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P24_S2	We are also likely to continue to face intense competition from other companies for available acquisition opportunities.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P24_S3	In addition, because improved technology has enhanced the ability to recover oil and natural gas, contract drillers may continue to build new, high technology rigs and providers of pressure pumping services may continue to build new, high horsepower equipment.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	There can be no assurance that we will:
889900_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	successfully improve our financial condition, results of operations, business or prospects as a result of any completed acquisition or the building of new drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	We may incur substantial indebtedness to finance future acquisitions, build new drilling rigs or build new pressure pumping equipment and also may issue equity, convertible or debt securities in connection with any such acquisitions or building program.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Debt service requirements could represent a significant burden on our results of operations and financial condition, and the issuance of additional equity would be dilutive to existing stockholders.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Also, continued growth could strain our management, operations, employees and other resources.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	The Nature of our Business Operations Presents Inherent Risks of Loss that, if not Insured or Indemnified Against, Could Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Our operations are subject to many hazards inherent in the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses, which in turn could cause personal injury or death, work stoppage, or serious damage to our equipment.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Our operations could also cause environmental and reservoir damages.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P29_S2	We maintain insurance coverage and have indemnification agreements with many of our customers.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P29_S3	However, there is no assurance that such insurance or indemnification agreements would be enforceable or adequately protect us against liability or losses from all consequences of these hazards.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P29_S4	Additionally, there can be no assurance that insurance would be available to cover any or all of these risks, or, even if available, that insurance premiums or other costs would not rise significantly in the future, so as to make the cost of such insurance prohibitive.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	It is possible that a customer or insurer could fail or be unable to meet its indemnification or insurance obligations, which could result in a material loss.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P30_S1	Moreover, we could suffer a material loss if we were to become subject to an unexpected judgment against us for which we are uninsured, for which indemnification is unenforceable or otherwise not available or that is beyond the amounts we reserved or anticipated incurring.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P30_S2	Incurring a liability for which we are not fully insured or indemnified could materially affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We have also elected in some cases to accept a greater amount of risk through increased deductibles on certain insurance policies.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P31_S1	For example, we generally maintain a $1.0 million per occurrence deductible on our workers compensation and equipment insurance coverages and a $2.0 million per occurrence self insured retention on our general liability insurance coverage.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Difficulties Integrating Our Recently Acquired Pressure Pumping Assets Could Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P33_S0	We expect that our recently acquired pressure pumping assets will complement and expand our business.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P33_S1	Successfully integrating the acquired business depends on our ability to integrate the acquired assets and personnel and to maintain and grow the acquired customer base.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P33_S2	We may encounter challenges in integrating the acquired business with our existing operations and management.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P33_S3	We may not be able to fully take advantage of expected business opportunities, including successfully developing new markets and retaining acquired customers.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P33_S4	The integration of the new business may place additional strain on our management.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P33_S5	In addition, the acquired business may not achieve anticipated results.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P33_S6	If the acquired business is not successfully integrated, our operating results could be adversely affected.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P34_S0	We have borrowings outstanding under a term loan and our senior notes.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P34_S1	These obligations are guaranteed by each of our existing subsidiaries other than immaterial subsidiaries.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P34_S2	Our ability to meet our interest and principal payment obligations depends in large part on dividends paid to us by our subsidiaries.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P35_S0	generate sufficient cash flows to pay us dividends, we may be unable to meet our interest and principal payment obligations.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Environmental Laws and Regulations, Including Violations Thereof Could Materially Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P37_S0	All of our operations and facilities are subject to numerous Federal, state, foreign and local environmental laws, rules and regulations, including, without limitation, laws concerning the containment and disposal of hazardous substances, oil field waste and other waste materials, the use of underground storage tanks, and the use of underground injection wells.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P37_S1	The cost of compliance with these laws and regulations could be substantial.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P37_S2	A failure to comply with these requirements could expose us to substantial civil and criminal penalties.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P38_S0	In addition, environmental laws and regulations in the United States and Canada impose a variety of requirements on responsible parties related to the prevention of oil spills and liability for damages from such spills.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P38_S1	As an owner and operator of land-based drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment, we may be deemed to be a responsible party under these laws and regulations.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Potential Legislation and Regulation Covering Hydraulic Fracturing Could Increase Our Costs and Result in Operational Delays.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Members of the U.S. Congress and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (the EPA ) are reviewing more stringent regulation of hydraulic fracturing, a technology employed by our pressure pumping business, which involves the injection of water, sand and chemicals under pressure into rock formations to stimulate oil and natural gas production.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P40_S1	Both the EPA and the U.S. Congress are studying whether there is any link between hydraulic fracturing activities and soil or ground water contamination.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P40_S2	As part of their respective studies, the House Subcommittee on Energy and Environment and the EPA each sent requests to a number of companies, including our company for information on their hydraulic fracturing practices.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P40_S3	We have responded to each of the inquiries.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P40_S4	In addition, legislation has been proposed in the U.S. Congress to amend the federal Safe Drinking Water Act to require the disclosure of chemicals used by the oil and gas industry in the hydraulic fracturing process, which could make it easier for third parties opposing the hydraulic fracturing process to initiate legal proceedings based on allegations that specific chemicals used in the fracturing process are impairing ground water or causing other damage.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P40_S5	These bills, if adopted, could establish an additional level of regulation at the federal or state level that could lead to operational delays or increased operating costs and could result in additional regulatory burdens that could make it more difficult to perform hydraulic fracturing and increase our costs of compliance and doing business.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Certain states have adopted or are considering similar disclosure legislation.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P41_S1	Additional regulation could increase the costs of conducting our business and could materially reduce our business opportunities and revenues if our customers decrease their levels of activity in response to such regulation.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P42_S0	We are aware of the increasing focus of local, state, national and international regulatory bodies on GHG emissions and climate change issues.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P42_S1	We are also aware of legislation proposed by United States lawmakers and the Canadian legislature to reduce GHG emissions, as well as GHG emissions regulations enacted by the EPA and the Canadian provinces of Alberta and British Columbia.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P42_S2	In 2007, the U.S. Supreme Court in Massachusetts, et al. v. Environmental Protection Agency held that carbon dioxide, a GHG, may be regulated as an air pollutant under the Clean Air Act, which could result in future regulations even if the U.S. Congress does not enact new legislation regarding such emissions.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P42_S3	We will continue to monitor and assess any new policies, legislation or regulations in the areas where we operate to determine the impact of GHG emissions and climate change on our operations and take appropriate actions, where necessary.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P42_S4	Any direct and indirect costs of meeting these requirements may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Anti-takeover Measures in Our Charter Documents and Under State Law Could Discourage an Acquisition and Thereby Affect the Related Purchase Price.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P44_S0	We are a Delaware corporation subject to the Delaware General Corporation Law, including Section 203, an anti-takeover law.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P44_S1	We have also enacted certain anti-takeover measures, including a stockholders rights plan.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P45_S0	addition, our Board of Directors has the authority to issue up to one million shares of preferred stock and to determine the price, rights (including voting rights), conversion ratios, preferences and privileges of that stock without further vote or action by the holders of the common stock.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P45_S1	As a result of these measures and others, potential acquirers might find it more difficult or be discouraged from attempting to effect an acquisition transaction with us.
889900_11_ITEM1A_P45_S2	This may deprive holders of our securities of certain opportunities to sell or otherwise dispose of the securities at above-market prices pursuant to any such transactions.

889900_11_ITEM7_P0_S0	Management Overview We are a leading provider of contract services to the North American oil and natural gas industry.
889900_11_ITEM7_P0_S1	Our services primarily involve the drilling, on a contract basis, of land-based oil and natural gas wells and, to a lesser extent, pressure pumping services.
889900_11_ITEM7_P0_S2	In addition to the aforementioned contract services, we also invest, on a working interest basis, in oil and natural gas properties.
889900_11_ITEM7_P0_S3	For the three years ended December 31, 2010, our operating revenues consisted of the following (dollars in thousands):
889900_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	We provide our contract services to oil and natural gas operators in many of the oil and natural gas producing regions of North America.
889900_11_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our contract drilling operations are focused in various regions of Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Colorado, Utah, Wyoming, Montana, North Dakota, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and western Canada, while our pressure pumping services are focused primarily in Texas and the Appalachian Basin.
889900_11_ITEM7_P1_S2	The oil and natural gas properties in which we hold interests are primarily located in Texas and New Mexico.
889900_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	Generally, the profitability of our business is impacted most by two primary factors in our contract drilling segment: our average number of rigs operating and our average revenue per operating day.
889900_11_ITEM7_P2_S1	During 2010, our average number of rigs operating was 168 compared to 91 in 2009 and 254 in 2008.
889900_11_ITEM7_P2_S2	Our average revenue per operating day was $17,670 in 2010 compared to $17,950 in 2009 and $19,380 in 2008.
889900_11_ITEM7_P2_S3	We had consolidated net income of $117 million for 2010 compared to a consolidated net loss of $38.3 million for 2009.
889900_11_ITEM7_P2_S4	The increase in consolidated net income was primarily due to our contract drilling segment experiencing an increase in the average number of rigs operating.
889900_11_ITEM7_P2_S5	Additionally, our pressure pumping segment experienced an increase in large multi-stage fracturing jobs in 2010 compared to 2009.
889900_11_ITEM7_P2_S6	This increase includes the fourth quarter contribution of a pressure pumping business we acquired on October 1, 2010, which significantly expanded our pressure pumping operations into new markets in the fourth quarter of 2010.
889900_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	Our revenues, profitability and cash flows are highly dependent upon prevailing prices for natural gas and oil.
889900_11_ITEM7_P3_S1	During periods of improved commodity prices, the capital spending budgets of oil and natural gas operators tend to expand, which generally results in increased demand for our contract services.
889900_11_ITEM7_P3_S2	Conversely, in periods when these commodity prices deteriorate, the demand for our contract services generally weakens and we experience downward pressure on pricing for our services.
889900_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	After reaching a peak in June 2008, there was a significant decline in oil and natural gas prices and a substantial deterioration in the global economic environment.
889900_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	As part of this deterioration, there was substantial uncertainty in the capital markets and access to financing was reduced.
889900_11_ITEM7_P4_S2	Due to these conditions, our customers reduced or curtailed their drilling programs, which resulted in a decrease in demand for our services, as evidenced by the decline in our monthly average number of rigs operating from a high of 283 in October 2008 to a low of 60 in June 2009.
889900_11_ITEM7_P4_S3	Our monthly average number of rigs operating has subsequently increased from the mid-year low in 2009 to 196 in December 2010.
889900_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	The decline in commodity prices and deterioration in the global economy resulted in certain of our customers experiencing an inability to pay suppliers, including us.
889900_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	We are also highly impacted by competition, the availability of excess equipment, labor issues and various other factors that could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_11_ITEM7_P5_S2	Please see Risk Factors in Item 1A of this Report.
889900_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	We believe that our liquidity as of December 31, 2010, which includes approximately $241 million in working capital and approximately $359 million available under our $400 million revolving credit facility, together with cash expected to be generated from operations, should provide us with sufficient ability to fund our current plans to build new equipment, make improvements to our existing equipment and pay cash dividends.
889900_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	credit facility or additional debt or equity financing.
889900_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	However, there can be no assurance that such capital will be available on reasonable terms, if at all.

889900_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	These letters of credit expire annually at various times during the year and are typically renewed.
889900_11_ITEM7_P8_S2	As of December 31, 2010, no amounts had been drawn under the letters of credit.
889900_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	As of December 31, 2010, we had commitments to purchase approximately $267 million of major equipment.
889900_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	Trading and investing We have not engaged in trading activities that include high-risk securities, such as derivatives and non-exchange traded contracts.
889900_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	We invest cash primarily in highly liquid, short-term investments such as overnight deposits and money market accounts.
889900_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	Description of business We conduct our contract drilling operations in Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Colorado, Utah, Wyoming, Montana, North Dakota, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and western Canada.
889900_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	For the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, revenue earned in Canada was $65.7 million, $45.4 million and $88.5 million, respectively.
889900_11_ITEM7_P12_S1	Additionally, we had long-lived assets located in Canada of $70.7 million and $69.2 million as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
889900_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	As of December 31, 2010, we had 356 marketable land-based drilling rigs.
889900_11_ITEM7_P13_S1	We provide pressure pumping services to oil and natural gas operators primarily in Texas and the Appalachian Basin.
889900_11_ITEM7_P13_S2	Pressure pumping services are primarily well stimulation and cementing for completion of new wells and remedial work on existing wells.
889900_11_ITEM7_P13_S3	We also invest, on a working interest basis, in oil and natural gas properties.
889900_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	In addition to established accounting policies, our consolidated financial statements are impacted by certain estimates and assumptions made by management.
889900_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	The following is a discussion of our critical accounting policies pertaining to property and equipment, oil and natural gas properties, goodwill, revenue recognition and the use of estimates.
889900_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	Property and equipment Property and equipment, including betterments which extend the useful life of the asset, are stated at cost.
889900_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	Maintenance and repairs are charged to expense when incurred.
889900_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	We provide for the depreciation of our property and equipment using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives.
889900_11_ITEM7_P16_S1	Our method of depreciation does not change when equipment becomes idle; we continue to depreciate idled equipment on a straight-line basis.
889900_11_ITEM7_P16_S2	No provision for salvage value is considered in determining depreciation of our property and equipment.
889900_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	We review our long-lived assets, including property and equipment, for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying values of certain assets may not be recovered over their estimated remaining useful lives.
889900_11_ITEM7_P17_S1	In connection with this review, assets are grouped at the lowest level at which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of other asset groupings.
889900_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	The cyclical nature of our industry has resulted in fluctuations in rig utilization over periods of time.
889900_11_ITEM7_P18_S1	Management believes that the contract drilling industry will continue to be cyclical and rig utilization will continue to fluctuate.
889900_11_ITEM7_P19_S0	Based on management s expectations of future trends, we estimate future cash flows over the life of the respective assets in our assessment of impairment.
889900_11_ITEM7_P19_S1	These estimates of cash flows are based on historical cyclical trends in the industry as well as management s expectations regarding the continuation of these trends in the future.
889900_11_ITEM7_P20_S0	Provisions for asset impairment are charged against income when estimated future cash flows, on an undiscounted basis, are less than the asset s net book value.
889900_11_ITEM7_P20_S1	Any provision for impairment is measured based on discounted cash flows.
889900_11_ITEM7_P21_S0	On a periodic basis, we evaluate our fleet of drilling rigs for marketability.
889900_11_ITEM7_P21_S1	In connection with our long term planning process, we evaluated our then-current fleet of marketable drilling rigs in 2010, 2009 and 2008 and identified four, 23 and 22 rigs, respectively, that we determined would no longer be marketed as rigs.
889900_11_ITEM7_P21_S2	The components comprising these rigs were evaluated, and those components with continuing utility to our other marketed rigs were transferred to other rigs or to our yards to be used as spare equipment.
889900_11_ITEM7_P21_S3	The remaining components of these rigs were impaired and the associated net book value of $4.2 million in 2010, $10.5 million in 2009 and $10.4 million in 2008 was expensed in our consolidated statements of operations as an impairment charge.
889900_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	In late 2008, we experienced a significant decrease in the number of our rigs operating and oil and natural gas prices decreased significantly.
889900_11_ITEM7_P22_S1	These events were deemed by us to be triggering events that required us to perform an assessment with respect to impairment of long-lived assets, including property and equipment, in our contract drilling segment.
889900_11_ITEM7_P22_S2	With respect to these long-lived assets, we estimated future cash flows over the expected life of the long-lived assets, which were comprised primarily of property and equipment, and determined that, on an undiscounted basis, expected cash flows exceeded the carrying value of the long-lived assets.
889900_11_ITEM7_P22_S3	Based on this assessment, no impairment was indicated in 2008.
889900_11_ITEM7_P22_S4	Due to a continued decrease in the operating levels in our contract drilling segment through the first three quarters of 2009, we again deemed it necessary to perform an impairment assessment of long-lived assets in our contract drilling segment in 2009.
889900_11_ITEM7_P22_S5	Based on the estimated undiscounted cash flows associated with the assets, we determined that no impairment was indicated in 2009.
889900_11_ITEM7_P22_S6	In light of the recent favorable trends in rig utilization and revenue per operating day experienced by us and our peers, we concluded that no triggering event had occurred in 2010 with respect to our contract drilling segment.
889900_11_ITEM7_P22_S7	We also concluded that no triggering event had occurred with respect to our pressure pumping segment in 2010, 2009 or 2008.
889900_11_ITEM7_P22_S8	Impairment considerations related to our oil and natural gas segment are discussed below.
889900_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	Oil and natural gas properties Working interests in oil and natural gas properties are accounted for using the successful efforts method of accounting.
889900_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	Under the successful efforts method of accounting, exploration costs which result in the discovery of oil and natural gas reserves and all development costs are capitalized to the appropriate well.
889900_11_ITEM7_P24_S1	Exploration costs which do not result in discovering oil and natural gas reserves are charged to expense when such determination is made.
889900_11_ITEM7_P24_S2	Costs of exploratory wells are initially capitalized to wells-in-progress until the outcome of the drilling is known.
889900_11_ITEM7_P24_S3	We review wells-in-progress quarterly to determine whether sufficient progress is being made in assessing the reserves and economic viability of the respective projects.
889900_11_ITEM7_P24_S4	If no progress has been made in assessing the reserves and economic viability of a project after one year following the completion of drilling, we consider the well costs to be impaired and recognize the costs as expense.
889900_11_ITEM7_P24_S5	Geological and geophysical costs, including seismic costs and costs to carry and retain undeveloped properties, are charged to expense when incurred.
889900_11_ITEM7_P24_S6	The capitalized costs of both developmental and successful exploratory type wells, consisting of lease and well equipment, lease acquisition costs and intangible development costs, are depreciated, depleted and amortized on the units-of-production method, based on engineering estimates of proved oil and natural gas reserves for each respective field.
889900_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	We review our proved oil and natural gas properties for impairment whenever a triggering event occurs, such as downward revisions in reserve estimates or decreases in oil and natural gas prices.
889900_11_ITEM7_P25_S1	Proved properties are grouped by field and undiscounted cash flow estimates are prepared based on our expectation of future commodity prices over the lives of the respective fields.
889900_11_ITEM7_P25_S2	These cash flow estimates are reviewed by an independent petroleum engineer.
889900_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	If the net book value of a field exceeds its undiscounted cash flow estimate, impairment expense is measured and recognized as the difference between net book value and discounted cash flow.
889900_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	The discounted cash flow estimates used in measuring impairment are based on our expectations of future commodity prices over the life of the respective field.
889900_11_ITEM7_P28_S0	We review unproved oil and natural gas properties quarterly to assess potential impairment.
889900_11_ITEM7_P28_S1	Our impairment assessment is made on a lease-by-lease basis and considers factors such as our intent to drill, lease terms and abandonment of an area.
889900_11_ITEM7_P29_S0	If an unproved property is determined to be impaired, the related property costs are expensed.
889900_11_ITEM7_P29_S1	Impairment expense related to proved and unproved oil and natural gas properties totaled approximately $792,000, $3.7 million and $4.4 million for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively, and is included in depreciation, depletion and impairment in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
889900_11_ITEM7_P30_S0	Goodwill Goodwill is considered to have an indefinite useful economic life and is not amortized.
889900_11_ITEM7_P30_S1	We assess impairment of our goodwill annually as of December 31, or on an interim basis if events or circumstances indicate that the fair value of goodwill may have decreased below its carrying value.
889900_11_ITEM7_P30_S2	Goodwill impairment testing is performed at the level of our reporting units.
889900_11_ITEM7_P30_S3	Our reporting units have been determined to be the same as our operating segments.
889900_11_ITEM7_P31_S0	In connection with our annual impairment assessment of goodwill, we compare the fair value of the reporting unit with its carrying value.
889900_11_ITEM7_P31_S1	If the fair value exceeds the carrying value, no impairment is indicated.
889900_11_ITEM7_P31_S2	If the carrying value exceeds the fair value, we measure any impairment of goodwill in that reporting unit by allocating the fair value to the identifiable assets and liabilities of the reporting unit based on their respective fair values.
889900_11_ITEM7_P32_S0	unallocated fair value would equal the implied fair value of goodwill, and if that amount is below the carrying value of goodwill, an impairment charge is recognized.
889900_11_ITEM7_P33_S0	In connection with our annual goodwill impairment assessment performed as of December 31, 2008, we performed an impairment test of goodwill recorded in our contract drilling and drilling and completion fluids reporting units.
889900_11_ITEM7_P33_S1	In light of the adverse market conditions affecting our common stock price beginning in the fourth quarter of 2008 and continuing into 2009, including a significant decrease in the average number of our rigs operating and a significant decline in oil and natural gas commodity prices, we utilized a discounted cash flow methodology to estimate the fair values of our reporting units.
889900_11_ITEM7_P33_S2	In completing the first step of our analysis, we used a three-year projection of discounted cash flows, plus a terminal value determined using the constant growth method to estimate the fair value of our reporting units.
889900_11_ITEM7_P33_S3	In developing these fair value estimates, we applied key assumptions, including an assumed discount rate of 13.99% for all reporting units, an assumed long-term growth rate of 3.50% for the contract drilling reporting unit and an assumed long-term growth rate of 2.00% for the drilling and completion fluids reporting unit.
889900_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	Based on the results of the first step of the impairment test in 2008, we concluded that no impairment was indicated in our contract drilling reporting unit as the estimated fair value of that reporting unit exceeded its carrying value.
889900_11_ITEM7_P34_S1	However, an impairment was indicated in our drilling and completion fluids reporting unit as the estimated fair value of that reporting unit was less than its carrying value.
889900_11_ITEM7_P34_S2	In validating this conclusion, we considered the results of our long-lived asset impairment tests and performed sensitivity analyses of the key assumptions used in deriving the respective fair values of our reporting units.
889900_11_ITEM7_P34_S3	We then performed the second step of the analysis of our drilling and completion fluids reporting unit, which included allocating the estimated fair value to the identifiable tangible and intangible assets and liabilities of this reporting unit based on their respective values.
889900_11_ITEM7_P34_S4	This allocation indicated no residual value for goodwill, and accordingly we recorded an impairment charge of approximately $10.0 million in our December 31, 2008 statement of operations.
889900_11_ITEM7_P34_S5	We exited the drilling and completion fluids business on January 20, 2010, and the 2008 impairment charge is included in our loss from discontinued operations in our statement of operations for the year ended December 31, 2008.
889900_11_ITEM7_P35_S0	We performed our annual goodwill impairment assessment as of December 31, 2009 related to the $86.2 million in goodwill recorded in our contract drilling reporting unit.
889900_11_ITEM7_P36_S0	In completing the first step of our analysis, we used a three-year projection of discounted cash flows, plus a terminal value determined using the constant growth method to estimate the fair value of the reporting unit.
889900_11_ITEM7_P36_S1	In developing this fair value estimate, we applied key assumptions, including an assumed discount rate of 15.42% and an assumed long-term growth rate of 3.50%.
889900_11_ITEM7_P36_S2	Based on the results of the first step of the impairment test in 2009, we concluded that no impairment was indicated in our contract drilling reporting unit as the estimated fair value of that reporting unit exceeded its carrying value.
889900_11_ITEM7_P37_S0	We performed our annual goodwill impairment assessment as of December 31, 2010.
889900_11_ITEM7_P38_S0	In completing the first step of our analysis, we estimated our enterprise value based on our market capitalization as determined by reference to the closing price of our common stock during the fifteen days before and after year end.
889900_11_ITEM7_P38_S1	We allocated the enterprise value to our reporting units and determined that the fair values of our reporting units were in excess of their carrying value.
889900_11_ITEM7_P38_S2	As a result, we concluded that no impairment of goodwill was indicated as of December 31, 2010.
889900_11_ITEM7_P39_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2010, we recorded goodwill in our pressure pumping reporting unit in connection with our acquisition of a pressure pumping business.
889900_11_ITEM7_P39_S1	The goodwill associated with this acquisition was estimated to be $67.6 million.
889900_11_ITEM7_P40_S0	In the event that market conditions weaken, we may be required to record an impairment of goodwill in our contract drilling or pressure pumping reporting units in the future, and such impairment could be material.
889900_11_ITEM7_P41_S0	Revenue recognition Revenues are recognized when services are performed, except for revenues earned under turnkey contract drilling arrangements which are recognized using the completed-contract method of accounting.
889900_11_ITEM7_P41_S1	We follow the percentage-of-completion method of accounting for footage contract drilling arrangements.
889900_11_ITEM7_P41_S2	Under the percentage-of-completion method, management estimates are relied upon in the determination of the total estimated expenses to be incurred drilling the well.
889900_11_ITEM7_P41_S3	Due to the nature of turnkey contract drilling arrangements and the risks therein, we follow the completed-contract method of accounting for such arrangements.
889900_11_ITEM7_P42_S0	Under this method, revenues and expenses related to a well-in-progress are deferred and recognized in the period the well is completed.
889900_11_ITEM7_P42_S1	Provisions for losses on incomplete or in-process wells are made when estimated total expenses are expected to exceed total revenues.
889900_11_ITEM7_P42_S2	We recognize as revenue reimbursements received from third parties for out-of-pocket expenses and account for those out-of-pocket expenses as direct costs.
889900_11_ITEM7_P43_S0	Except for two wells drilled under footage contacts in 2009, all of the wells we drilled in 2010, 2009 and 2008 were drilled under daywork contracts.
889900_11_ITEM7_P44_S0	Use of estimates The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make certain estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
889900_11_ITEM7_P44_S1	Actual results could differ from such estimates.
889900_11_ITEM7_P45_S0	Key estimates used by management include:
889900_11_ITEM7_P46_S0	reserves for self-insured levels of insurance coverage.
889900_11_ITEM7_P47_S0	For additional information on our accounting policies, see Note 1 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included as a part of Item 8 of this Report.

889900_11_ITEM7_P55_S0	On August 19, 2010, we entered into a Credit Agreement (the 2010 Credit Agreement ).
889900_11_ITEM7_P55_S1	The 2010 Credit Agreement is a committed senior unsecured credit facility that includes a revolving credit facility and a term loan facility.
889900_11_ITEM7_P55_S2	The 2010 Credit Agreement replaced a previous unsecured revolving credit facility.
889900_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	The revolving credit facility permits aggregate borrowings of up to $400 million and contains a letter of credit facility that is limited to $150 million and a swing line facility that is limited to $40 million.
889900_11_ITEM7_P56_S1	Subject to customary conditions, we may request that the lenders aggregate commitments with respect to the revolving credit facility be increased by up to $100 million, not to exceed total commitments of $500 million.
889900_11_ITEM7_P56_S2	The maturity date for the revolving credit facility is August 19, 2013.
889900_11_ITEM7_P57_S0	The term loan facility provided for a loan of $100 million which was funded on August 19, 2010.
889900_11_ITEM7_P57_S1	The term loan facility is payable in quarterly principal installments commencing November 19, 2010, and the installment amounts vary from 1.25% of the original principal amount for each of the first four quarterly installments, 2.50% of the original principal amount for each of the subsequent eight quarterly installments, 5.00% of the original principal amount for the next subsequent three quarterly installments, and the remainder due at maturity.
889900_11_ITEM7_P57_S2	The maturity date for the term loan facility is August 19, 2014.
889900_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	Loans under the 2010 Credit Agreement bear interest by reference, at our election, to the LIBOR rate or base rate.
889900_11_ITEM7_P58_S1	The applicable margin on LIBOR rate loans varies from 2.75% to 3.75% and the applicable margin on base rate loans varies from 1.75% to 2.75%, in each case determined based upon our debt to capitalization ratio.
889900_11_ITEM7_P58_S2	As of December 31, 2010, the applicable margin on LIBOR rate loans was 2.75% and the applicable margin on base rate loans was 1.75%.
889900_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	A letter of credit fee is payable by us equal to the applicable margin for LIBOR rate loans times the daily amount available to be drawn under outstanding letters of credit.
889900_11_ITEM7_P59_S1	The commitment fee payable to the lenders for the unused portion of the revolving credit facility varies from 0.50% to 0.75% based upon our debt to capitalization ratio and was 0.50% as of December 31, 2010.
889900_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	The 2010 Credit Agreement contains customary representations, warranties, indemnities and affirmative and negative covenants.
889900_11_ITEM7_P60_S1	The 2010 Credit Agreement also requires compliance with two financial covenants.
889900_11_ITEM7_P60_S2	We must not permit our debt to capitalization ratio to exceed 45% at any time.
889900_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	The 2010 Credit Agreement generally defines the debt to capitalization ratio as the ratio of (a) total borrowed money indebtedness to (b) the sum of such indebtedness plus consolidated net worth, with consolidated net worth determined as of the last day of the most recently ended fiscal quarter.
889900_11_ITEM7_P61_S1	We also must not permit the interest coverage ratio as of the last day of a fiscal quarter to be less than 3.00 to 1.00.
889900_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	The 2010 Credit Agreement generally defines the interest coverage ratio as the ratio of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization ( EBITDA ) of the four prior fiscal quarters to interest charges for the same period.
889900_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	We do not expect that the restrictions and covenants will impair our ability to operate or react to opportunities that might arise.
889900_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	As of December 31, 2010, we had $98.8 million principal amount outstanding under the term loan facility at an interest rate of 3.125% and no borrowings outstanding under the revolving credit facility.
889900_11_ITEM7_P64_S1	We had $41.2 million in letters of credit outstanding at December 31, 2010, and as a result, we had available borrowing capacity of approximately $359 million at that date.
889900_11_ITEM7_P65_S0	On October 5, 2010, we completed the issuance and sale of $300 million in aggregate principal amount of our 4.97% Series A Senior Notes due October 5, 2020 (the Notes ) in a private placement.
889900_11_ITEM7_P65_S1	A portion of the proceeds from the Notes was used to repay a $200 million borrowing on our revolving credit facility, which had been drawn to fund a portion of a business acquisition that closed on October 1, 2010.
889900_11_ITEM7_P66_S0	The Notes bear interest at a rate of 4.97% per annum and were priced at 100% of the principal amount of the Notes.
889900_11_ITEM7_P66_S1	We will pay interest on the Notes on April 5 and October 5 of each year commencing on April 5, 2011.
889900_11_ITEM7_P66_S2	The Notes will mature on October 5, 2020.
889900_11_ITEM7_P66_S3	The Notes are prepayable at our option, in whole or in part, provided that in the case of a partial prepayment, prepayment must be in an amount not less than 5% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes then outstanding, at any time and from time to time at 100% of the principal amount prepaid, plus accrued and unpaid interest to the prepayment date, plus a make-whole premium as specified in the note purchase agreement.
889900_11_ITEM7_P66_S4	We must offer to prepay the Notes upon the occurrence of any change of control.
889900_11_ITEM7_P66_S5	In addition, we must offer to prepay the Notes upon the occurrence of certain asset dispositions if the proceeds therefrom are not timely reinvested in productive assets.
889900_11_ITEM7_P66_S6	If any offer to prepay is accepted, the purchase price of each prepaid Note is 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest thereon to the prepayment date.
889900_11_ITEM7_P67_S0	The note purchase agreement requires compliance with two financial covenants.
889900_11_ITEM7_P67_S1	We must not permit our debt to capitalization ratio to exceed 50% at any time.
889900_11_ITEM7_P68_S0	The note purchase agreement generally defines the debt to capitalization ratio as the ratio of (a) total borrowed money indebtedness to (b) the sum of such indebtedness plus consolidated net worth, with consolidated net worth determined as of the last day of the most recently ended fiscal quarter.
889900_11_ITEM7_P68_S1	We also must not permit the interest coverage ratio as of the last day of a fiscal quarter to be less than 2.50 to 1.00.
889900_11_ITEM7_P69_S0	The note purchase agreement generally defines the interest coverage ratio as the ratio for the four prior quarters of EBITDA to interest charges for the same period.
889900_11_ITEM7_P69_S1	We were in compliance with these financial covenants as of December 31, 2010.
889900_11_ITEM7_P69_S2	We do not expect that the restrictions and covenants will impair our ability to operate or react to opportunities that might arise.
889900_11_ITEM7_P70_S0	Events of default under the note purchase agreement include failure to pay principal or interest when due, failure to comply with the financial and operational covenants, a cross default event, a judgment in excess of a threshold event, the guaranty agreement ceasing to be enforceable, the occurrence of certain ERISA events, a change of control event and bankruptcy and other insolvency events.
889900_11_ITEM7_P70_S1	If an event of default occurs and is continuing, then holders of a majority in principal amount of the Notes have the right to declare all the notes then-outstanding to be immediately due and payable.
889900_11_ITEM7_P70_S2	In addition, if we default in payments on any Note, then until such defaults are cured, the holder thereof may declare all the Notes held by it to be immediately due and payable.
