889900_13_ITEM1_P3_S0	We own and operate one of the largest fleets of land-based drilling rigs in the United States.
889900_13_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Company was formed in 1978 and reincorporated in 1993 as a Delaware corporation.
889900_13_ITEM1_P5_S0	Our contract drilling business operates in the continental United States, Alaska, and western and northern Canada.
889900_13_ITEM1_P5_S1	As of December 31, 2012, we had a drilling fleet that consisted of 314 marketable land-based drilling rigs.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S0	A drilling rig includes the structure, power source and machinery necessary to cause a drill bit to penetrate the earth to a depth desired by the customer.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S1	A drilling rig is considered marketable at a point in time if it is operating or can be made ready to operate without significant capital expenditures.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S2	We also have a substantial inventory of drill pipe and drilling rig components.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S3	We provide pressure pumping services to oil and natural gas operators primarily in Texas and the Appalachian Basin.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S4	Pressure pumping services consist primarily of well stimulation and cementing for completion of new wells and remedial work on existing wells.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S5	We also own and invest in oil and natural gas assets as a non-operating working interest owner.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S6	Our oil and natural gas working interests are located primarily in Texas and New Mexico.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S7	Prior to January 20, 2010, we provided drilling fluids, completion fluids and related services to oil and natural gas operators offshore in the Gulf of Mexico and on land in Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Louisiana.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S8	We sold our drilling and completion fluids services business on January 20, 2010.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S9	On October 1, 2010, we acquired the assets and operations of a pressure pumping business and an electric wireline business.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S10	The electric wireline business that we acquired was classified as held for sale at December 31, 2010 and sold on January 27, 2011.
889900_13_ITEM1_P6_S11	The results of our drilling and completion fluids services business and our electric wireline business are presented as discontinued operations in this Report.
889900_13_ITEM1_P7_S0	Industry Segments Our revenues, operating profits and identifiable assets are primarily attributable to three industry segments:
889900_13_ITEM1_P8_S0	oil and natural gas exploration and production.
889900_13_ITEM1_P8_S1	All of our industry segments had operating profits in 2012, 2011 and 2010.
889900_13_ITEM1_P8_S2	See Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and Note 15 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included as a part of Items 7 and 8, respectively, of this Report for financial information pertaining to these industry segments.
889900_13_ITEM1_P9_S0	We market our contract drilling services to major and independent oil and natural gas operators.
889900_13_ITEM1_P9_S1	As of December 31, 2012, we had 314 marketable land-based drilling rigs based in the following regions:
889900_13_ITEM1_P10_S0	18 in western and northern Canada.
889900_13_ITEM1_P10_S1	Our marketable drilling rigs have rated maximum depth capabilities ranging from 5,250 feet to 25,000 feet.
889900_13_ITEM1_P10_S2	Of these drilling rigs, 167 are electric rigs and 147 are mechanical rigs.
889900_13_ITEM1_P11_S0	An electric rig differs from a mechanical rig in that the electric rig converts the power from its engines (the sole energy source for a mechanical rig) into electricity to power the rig.
889900_13_ITEM1_P11_S1	We also have a substantial inventory of drill pipe and drilling rig components, which may be used in the activation of additional drilling rigs or as replacement parts for marketable rigs.
889900_13_ITEM1_P12_S0	Drilling rigs are typically equipped with engines, drawworks, masts, pumps to circulate the drilling fluid, blowout preventers, drill pipe and other related equipment.
889900_13_ITEM1_P13_S0	Over time, components on a drilling rig are replaced or rebuilt.
889900_13_ITEM1_P13_S1	We spend significant funds each year as part of a program to modify, upgrade and maintain our drilling rigs to ensure that our drilling equipment is competitive.
889900_13_ITEM1_P13_S2	We have spent over $2.2 billion during the last three years on capital expenditures to (1) build new land drilling rigs and (2) modify, upgrade and extend the lives of components of our drilling fleet.
889900_13_ITEM1_P13_S3	During fiscal years 2012, 2011 and 2010, we spent approximately $745 million, $785 million and $656 million, respectively, on these capital expenditures.
889900_13_ITEM1_P14_S0	Depth and complexity of the well and drill site conditions are the principal factors in determining the specifications of the rig selected for a particular job.
889900_13_ITEM1_P15_S0	Our contract drilling operations depend on the availability of drill pipe, drill bits, replacement parts and other related rig equipment, fuel and other materials and qualified personnel.
889900_13_ITEM1_P15_S1	Some of these have been in short supply from time to time.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S0	Drilling Contracts Most of our drilling contracts are with established customers on a competitive bid or negotiated basis.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S1	Our drilling contracts are either on a well-to-well basis or a term basis.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S2	Well-to-well contracts are generally short-term in nature and cover the drilling of a single well or a series of wells.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S3	Term contracts are entered into for a specified period of time (frequently six months to three years) and provide for the use of the drilling rig to drill multiple wells.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S4	During 2012, our average number of days to drill a well (which includes moving to the drill site, rigging up and rigging down) was approximately 22 days.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S5	Our drilling contracts obligate us to provide and operate a drilling rig and to pay certain operating expenses, including wages of our drilling personnel and necessary maintenance expenses.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S6	Most drilling contracts are subject to termination by the customer on short notice and may or may not contain provisions for an early termination payment to us in the event that the contract is terminated by the customer.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S7	We believe that our drilling contracts generally provide for indemnification rights and obligations that are customary for the markets in which we conduct those operations; however, each drilling contract contains the actual terms setting forth our rights and obligations and those of the customer, any of which rights and obligations may deviate from what is customary due to particular industry conditions, customer requirements or other factors.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S8	Our drilling contracts provide for payment on a daywork, footage or turnkey basis, or a combination thereof.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S9	In each case, we provide the rig and crews.
889900_13_ITEM1_P16_S10	Our bid for each job depends upon location, depth and anticipated complexity of the well, on-site drilling conditions, equipment to be used, estimated risks involved, estimated duration of the job, availability of drilling rigs and other factors particular to each proposed well.
889900_13_ITEM1_P17_S0	Under daywork contracts, we provide the drilling rig and crew to the customer.
889900_13_ITEM1_P17_S1	The customer supervises the drilling of the well.
889900_13_ITEM1_P17_S2	Our compensation is based on a contracted rate per day during the period the drilling rig is utilized.
889900_13_ITEM1_P17_S3	We often receive a lower rate when the drilling rig is moving or when drilling operations are interrupted or restricted by adverse weather conditions or other conditions beyond our control.
889900_13_ITEM1_P18_S0	Daywork contracts typically provide separately for mobilization of the drilling rig.
889900_13_ITEM1_P18_S1	All of the wells we drilled in 2012, 2011 and 2010 were under daywork contracts.
889900_13_ITEM1_P19_S0	Under footage contracts, we contract to drill a well to a certain depth under specified conditions for a fixed price per foot.
889900_13_ITEM1_P19_S1	The customer provides drilling fluids, casing, cementing and well design expertise.
889900_13_ITEM1_P20_S0	If we drill the well in less time than estimated, we have the opportunity to improve our profits over those that would be attainable under a daywork contract.
889900_13_ITEM1_P20_S1	Profits are reduced and losses may be incurred if the well requires more days to drill to the contracted depth than estimated.
889900_13_ITEM1_P21_S0	Footage contracts generally contain greater risks for a drilling contractor than daywork contracts.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S0	Under footage contracts, the drilling contractor typically assumes certain risks associated with loss of the well from fire, blowouts and other risks.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S1	Although we have entered into footage contracts in the past, we did not drill any wells under footage contracts in the past three years.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S2	Under turnkey contracts, we contract to drill a well to a certain depth under specified conditions for a fixed fee.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S3	In a turnkey arrangement, we are required to bear the costs of services, supplies and equipment beyond those typically provided under a footage contract.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S4	In addition to the drilling rig and crew, we are required to provide the drilling and completion fluids, casing, cementing, and the technical well design and engineering services during the drilling process.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S5	We also typically assume certain risks associated with drilling the well such as fires, blowouts, cratering of the well bore and other such risks.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S6	Compensation occurs only when the agreed-upon scope of the work has been completed, which requires us to make larger up-front working capital commitments prior to receiving payments under a turnkey drilling contract.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S7	Under a turnkey contract, we have the opportunity to improve our profits if the drilling process goes as expected and there are no complications or time delays.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S8	Given the increased exposure we have under a turnkey contract, however, profits can be significantly reduced and losses can be incurred if complications or delays occur during the drilling process.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S9	Turnkey contracts generally involve the highest degree of risk among the three different types of drilling contracts.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S10	Although we have entered into turnkey contracts in the past, we did not drill any wells under turnkey contracts in the past three years.
889900_13_ITEM1_P22_S11	Contract Drilling Activity Information regarding our contract drilling activity for the last three years follows:
889900_13_ITEM1_P23_S0	(1) A rig is considered to be operating if it is earning revenue pursuant to a contract on a given day.
889900_13_ITEM1_P24_S0	We have made significant upgrades during the last several years to our drilling fleet to match the needs of our customers.
889900_13_ITEM1_P24_S1	While conventional wells remain an important source of natural gas and oil, our customers have expanded the development of shale and other unconventional wells to help supply the long-term demand for natural gas and oil in North America.
889900_13_ITEM1_P25_S0	To address our customers needs for drilling wells in the newer horizontal shale and other unconventional resource plays, we have expanded our areas of operation and improved the capability of our drilling fleet.
889900_13_ITEM1_P25_S1	We have delivered new APEX rigs to the market and have made performance and safety improvements to existing high capacity rigs.
889900_13_ITEM1_P26_S0	APEX 1500 rigs are 1,500 horsepower electric rigs with advanced electronic drilling systems, 500 ton top drives, iron roughnecks, hydraulic catwalks, and other highly automated pipe handling equipment.
889900_13_ITEM1_P26_S1	APEX 1000 rigs are 1,000 horsepower electric rigs with advanced technology equipment similar to the APEX 1500 rigs, but with a more compact design to fit on smaller locations.
889900_13_ITEM1_P26_S2	APEX WALKING rigs are designed to efficiently drill multiple wells from a single pad, by walking between the wellbores without requiring time to lower the mast and lay down the drill pipe.
889900_13_ITEM1_P26_S3	Some APEX 1500 and APEX 1000 rigs have also been equipped with walking systems.
889900_13_ITEM1_P27_S0	As of December 31, 2012 our drilling fleet was comprised of the following: We estimate the depth capacity with respect to our marketable rigs as of December 31, 2012 to be as follows: At December 31, 2012, we owned and operated 312 trucks and 410 trailers used to rig down, transport and rig up our drilling rigs.
889900_13_ITEM1_P27_S1	Our ownership of trucks and trailers reduces our dependency upon third parties for these services and generally enhances the efficiency of our contract drilling operations in periods of high drilling rig utilization.
889900_13_ITEM1_P27_S2	We perform repair and overhaul work to our drilling rig equipment at our yard facilities located in Texas, Oklahoma, Wyoming, Colorado, Pennsylvania and western Canada.
889900_13_ITEM1_P27_S3	We provide pressure pumping services to oil and natural gas operators primarily in Texas (Southwest Region) and the Appalachian Basin (Northeast Region).
889900_13_ITEM1_P27_S4	Pressure pumping services consist of well stimulation and cementing for the completion of new wells and remedial work on existing wells.
889900_13_ITEM1_P27_S5	Wells drilled in shale formations and other unconventional plays require well stimulation through fracturing to allow the flow of oil and natural gas.
889900_13_ITEM1_P27_S6	This is accomplished by pumping fluids under pressure into the well bore to fracture the formation.
889900_13_ITEM1_P27_S7	Many wells in conventional plays also receive well stimulation services.
889900_13_ITEM1_P28_S0	The cementing process inserts material between the wall of the well bore and the casing to support and stabilize the casing.
889900_13_ITEM1_P29_S0	Our pressure pumping operations are conducted pursuant to a work order for a specific job or pursuant to a term contract.
889900_13_ITEM1_P30_S0	period of time and may include minimum revenue, usage or stage requirements.
889900_13_ITEM1_P30_S1	We are compensated based on a combination of charges for equipment, personnel, materials, mobilization and other items.
889900_13_ITEM1_P30_S2	We believe that our pressure pumping contracts generally provide for indemnification rights and obligations that are customary for the markets in which we conduct those operations; however, each pressure pumping contract contains the actual terms setting forth our rights and obligations and those of the customer, any of which rights and obligations may deviate from what is customary due to particular industry conditions, customer requirements or other factors.
889900_13_ITEM1_P31_S0	Equipment We have pressure pumping equipment used in providing hydraulic and nitrogen fracturing services as well as nitrogen, cementing and acid pumping services, with a total of approximately 758,000 hydraulic horsepower as of December 31, 2012.
889900_13_ITEM1_P31_S1	Pressure pumping equipment at December 31, 2012 included:
889900_13_ITEM1_P32_S0	Our pressure pumping operations are supported by a fleet of other equipment including blenders, tractors, manifold trailers and numerous trailers for transportation of materials to and from the worksite as well as bins for storage of materials at the worksite.
889900_13_ITEM1_P32_S1	Our pressure pumping operations require the use of acids, chemicals, proppants, fluid supplies and other materials, any of which can be in short supply, including severe shortages, from time to time.
889900_13_ITEM1_P32_S2	We purchase these materials from various suppliers.
889900_13_ITEM1_P32_S3	These purchases are made in the spot market or pursuant to other arrangements that do not cover all of our required supply and that sometimes require us to purchase the supply or pay liquidated damages if we do not purchase the material.
889900_13_ITEM1_P32_S4	Given the limited number of suppliers of certain of our materials, we may not always be able to make alternative arrangements if we are unable to reach an agreement with a supplier for delivery of any particular material or should one of our suppliers fail to timely deliver our materials.
889900_13_ITEM1_P33_S0	Oil and Natural Gas Interests We own and invest in oil and natural gas assets as a non-operating working interest owner.
889900_13_ITEM1_P33_S1	Our oil and natural gas working interests are located primarily in producing regions of Texas and New Mexico.
889900_13_ITEM1_P33_S2	Our oil and natural gas assets constituted approximately 1% of our consolidated assets as of December 31, 2012.
889900_13_ITEM1_P33_S3	The customers of each of our contract drilling and pressure pumping business segments are oil and natural gas operators.
889900_13_ITEM1_P33_S4	Our customer base includes both major and independent oil and natural gas operators.
889900_13_ITEM1_P33_S5	During 2012, no single customer accounted for 10% or more of our consolidated operating revenues.
889900_13_ITEM1_P34_S0	Competition Our contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses are highly competitive.
889900_13_ITEM1_P34_S1	Historically, available equipment used in these businesses has frequently exceeded demand.
889900_13_ITEM1_P34_S2	The price for our services is a key competitive factor, in part because equipment used in our businesses can be moved from one area to another in response to market conditions.
889900_13_ITEM1_P35_S0	of equipment, quality of personnel, service quality and safety record are key factors in determining which contractor is awarded a job.
889900_13_ITEM1_P36_S0	We expect that the market for land drilling and pressure pumping services will continue to be highly competitive.
889900_13_ITEM1_P37_S0	Government and Environmental Regulation All of our operations and facilities are subject to numerous federal, state, foreign, and local laws, rules and regulations related to various aspects of our business, including:
889900_13_ITEM1_P38_S0	To date, applicable environmental laws and regulations in the United States and Canada have not required the expenditure of significant resources outside the ordinary course of business.
889900_13_ITEM1_P38_S1	We do not anticipate any material capital expenditures for environmental control facilities or extraordinary expenditures to comply with environmental rules and regulations in the foreseeable future.
889900_13_ITEM1_P38_S2	However, compliance costs under existing laws or under any new requirements could become material, and we could incur liability in any instance of noncompliance.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S0	Our business is generally affected by political developments and by federal, state, foreign, and local laws, rules and regulations that relate to the oil and natural gas industry.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S1	The adoption of laws, rules and regulations affecting the oil and natural gas industry for economic, environmental and other policy reasons could increase costs relating to drilling, completion and production, and otherwise have an adverse effect on our operations.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S2	Federal, state, foreign and local environmental laws, rules and regulations currently apply to our operations and may become more stringent in the future.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S3	Any suspension or moratorium of the services we provide, whether or not short-term in nature, by a federal, state, foreign or local governmental authority, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S4	We believe we use operating and disposal practices that are standard in the industry.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S5	However, hydrocarbons and other materials may have been disposed of, or released in or under properties currently or formerly owned or operated by us or our predecessors, which may have resulted, or may result, in soil and groundwater contamination in certain locations.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S6	Any contamination found on, under or originating from the properties may be subject to remediation requirements under federal, state, foreign and local laws, rules and regulations.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S7	In addition, some of these properties have been operated by third parties over whom we have no control of their treatment of hydrocarbon and other materials or the manner in which they may have disposed of or released such materials.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S8	We could be required to remove or remediate wastes disposed of or released by prior owners or operators.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S9	In addition, it is possible we could be held responsible for oil and natural gas properties in which we own an interest but are not the operator.
889900_13_ITEM1_P39_S10	Some of the environmental laws and regulations that are applicable to our business operations are discussed in the following paragraphs, but the discussion does not cover all environmental laws and regulations that govern our operations.
889900_13_ITEM1_P40_S0	In the United States, the Federal Comprehensive Environmental Response Compensation and Liability Act of 1980, as amended, commonly known as CERCLA, and comparable state statutes impose strict liability on:
889900_13_ITEM1_P41_S0	persons who disposed of or arranged for the disposal of hazardous substances found at sites.
889900_13_ITEM1_P42_S0	The Federal Resource Conservation and Recovery Act ( RCRA ), as amended, and comparable state statutes govern the disposal of hazardous wastes.
889900_13_ITEM1_P43_S0	wastes from regulation, such exemptions by Congress under both CERCLA and RCRA may be deleted, limited, or modified in the future.
889900_13_ITEM1_P43_S1	If such changes are made to CERCLA and/or RCRA, we could be required to remove and remediate previously disposed of materials (including materials disposed of or released by prior owners or operators) from properties (including ground water contaminated with hydrocarbons) and to perform removal or remedial actions to prevent future contamination.
889900_13_ITEM1_P44_S0	The Federal Water Pollution Control Act and the Oil Pollution Act of 1990, as amended, and implementing regulations govern:
889900_13_ITEM1_P45_S0	The Oil Pollution Act imposes strict liability for a comprehensive and expansive list of damages from an oil spill into waters from facilities.
889900_13_ITEM1_P45_S1	Liability may be imposed for oil removal costs and a variety of public and private damages.
889900_13_ITEM1_P45_S2	Penalties may also be imposed for violation of federal safety, construction and operating regulations, and for failure to report a spill or to cooperate fully in a clean-up.
889900_13_ITEM1_P45_S3	The Oil Pollution Act also expands the authority and capability of the federal government to direct and manage oil spill clean-up and operations, and requires operators to prepare oil spill response plans in cases where it can reasonably be expected that substantial harm will be done to the environment by discharges on or into navigable waters.
889900_13_ITEM1_P46_S0	Failure to comply with ongoing requirements or inadequate cooperation during a spill event may subject a responsible party, such as us, to civil or criminal actions.
889900_13_ITEM1_P46_S1	Although the liability for owners and operators is the same under the Federal Water Pollution Act, the damages recoverable under the Oil Pollution Act are potentially much greater and can include natural resource damages.
889900_13_ITEM1_P47_S0	Our activities include the performance of hydraulic fracturing services to enhance the production of oil and natural gas from formations with low permeability, such as shales and other unconventional formations.
889900_13_ITEM1_P48_S0	Due to concerns raised relating to potential impacts of hydraulic fracturing on groundwater quality, legislative and regulatory efforts at the federal level and in some states have been initiated to render permitting and compliance requirements more stringent for hydraulic fracturing or prohibit the activity altogether.
889900_13_ITEM1_P48_S1	Such efforts could have an adverse effect on oil and natural gas production activities, which in turn could have an adverse effect on the hydraulic fracturing services that we render for our exploration and production customers.
889900_13_ITEM1_P48_S2	See Item 1A. Risk Factors Potential Legislation and Regulation Covering Hydraulic Fracturing Could Increase Our Costs and Limit or Delay Our Operations.
889900_13_ITEM1_P49_S0	In Canada, a variety of Canadian federal, provincial and municipal laws, rules and regulations impose, among other things, restrictions, liabilities and obligations in connection with the generation, handling, use, storage, transportation, treatment and disposal of hazardous substances and wastes and in connection with spills, releases and emissions of various substances to the environment.
889900_13_ITEM1_P49_S1	These laws, rules and regulations also require that facility sites and other properties associated with our operations be operated, maintained, abandoned and reclaimed to the satisfaction of applicable regulatory authorities.
889900_13_ITEM1_P49_S2	In addition, new projects or changes to existing projects may require the submission and approval of environmental assessments or permit applications.
889900_13_ITEM1_P49_S3	These laws, rules and regulations are subject to frequent change, and the clear trend is to place increasingly stringent limitations on activities that may affect the environment.
889900_13_ITEM1_P49_S4	Our operations are also subject to federal, state, foreign and local laws, rules and regulations for the control of air emissions, including the Federal Clean Air Act and the Canadian Environmental Protection Act.
889900_13_ITEM1_P49_S5	We and our customers may be required to make capital expenditures in the future for air pollution control equipment in connection with obtaining and maintaining operating permits and approvals for air emissions.
889900_13_ITEM1_P49_S6	For example, on August 16, 2012, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency ( EPA ) published final rules that establish new air emission control requirements for natural gas and NGL production, processing and transportation activities, including New Source Performance Standards ( NSPS ) and National Emissions Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants ( NESHAP ) that impose, among other things, new standards for completions of hydraulically fractured natural gas wells.
889900_13_ITEM1_P49_S7	For more information, please refer to our discussion under Item 1A. Risk Factors Environmental Laws and Regulations, Including Violations Thereof, Could Materially Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S0	We are aware of the increasing focus of local, state, national and international regulatory bodies on greenhouse gas ( GHG ) emissions and climate change issues.

889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S5	Risks and Insurance Our operations are subject to many hazards inherent in the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses, including inclement weather, blowouts, well fires, loss of well control, pollution and reservoir damage.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S6	These hazards could cause personal injury or death, work stoppage, and serious damage to equipment and other property, as well as significant environmental and reservoir damages.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S7	These risks could expose us to substantial liability for personal injury, wrongful death, property damage, loss of oil and natural gas production, pollution and other environmental damages.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S8	We have indemnification agreements with many of our customers, and we also maintain liability and other forms of insurance.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S9	In general, our drilling and pressure pumping contracts typically contain provisions requiring our customer to indemnify us for, among other things, reservoir and certain pollution damage.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S10	Our right to indemnification may, however, be unenforceable or limited due to negligent or willful acts or omissions by us, our subcontractors and/or suppliers.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S11	Our customers may dispute, or be unable to meet, their contractual indemnification obligations to us due to financial, legal or other reasons.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S12	Accordingly, we may be unable to transfer these risks to our customers by contract or indemnification agreements.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S13	Incurring a liability for which we are not fully indemnified or insured could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S14	We maintain insurance coverage of types and amounts that we believe to be customary for our businesses, but we are not fully insured against all risks, either because insurance is not available or because of the high premium costs.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S15	The insurance coverage that we maintain includes insurance for fire, windstorm and other risks of physical loss to our rigs and certain other assets, employer s liability, automobile liability, commercial general liability insurance, workers compensation and insurance for other specific risks.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S16	We cannot assure, however, that any insurance obtained by us will be adequate to cover any losses or liabilities, or that this insurance will continue to be available or available on terms that are acceptable to us.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S17	While we carry insurance to cover physical damage to, or loss of, our drilling rigs and certain other assets, such insurance does not cover the full replacement cost of the rigs or other assets.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S18	We have also elected in some cases to accept a greater amount of risk through increased deductibles on certain insurance policies.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S19	For example, we generally maintain a $1.0 million per occurrence deductible on our workers compensation and equipment insurance coverage and a $2.0 million per occurrence self-insured retention on our general liability insurance coverage.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S20	We self-insure a number of other risks, including loss of earnings and business interruption, and do not carry a significant amount of insurance to cover risks of underground reservoir damage.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S21	Our insurance will not in all situations provide sufficient funds to protect us from all liabilities that could result from our operations.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S22	Our coverage includes aggregate policy limits and exclusions.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S23	As a result, we retain the risk for any loss in excess of these limits or that is otherwise excluded from our coverage.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S24	There can be no assurance that insurance will be available to cover any or all of our operational risks, or, even if available, that insurance premiums or other costs will not rise significantly in the future, so as to make the cost of such insurance prohibitive or that our coverage will cover a specific loss.
889900_13_ITEM1_P50_S25	Further, we may experience difficulties in collecting from insurers or such insurers may deny all or a portion of our claims for insurance coverage.

889900_13_ITEM1_P53_S0	Raw Materials and Subcontractors We use many suppliers of raw materials and services.

889900_13_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Global Economic Conditions May Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Global economic conditions and volatility in commodity prices may cause our customers to reduce or curtail their drilling and well completion programs, which could result in a decrease in demand for our services.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P1_S2	In addition, uncertainty in the capital markets may result in reduced access to financing by our customers and reduced demand for our services.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P1_S3	Furthermore, these factors may result in certain of our customers experiencing an inability to pay suppliers, including us.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P1_S4	Although the significant deterioration in the global economic environment appeared to stabilize to some degree since 2009, there is no assurance that the global economic environment will not quickly deteriorate again due to one or more factors.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P1_S5	A deterioration in the global economic environment could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We Are Dependent on the Oil and Natural Gas Industry and Market Prices for Oil and Natural Gas.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Declines in Customers Operating and Capital Expenditures and in Oil and Natural Gas Prices May Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P2_S2	We depend on our customers willingness to make operating and capital expenditures to explore for, develop and produce oil and natural gas in North America.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P2_S3	If these expenditures decline, our business may suffer.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Our customers willingness to explore, develop and produce depends largely upon prevailing industry conditions that are influenced by numerous factors over which we have no control, such as:
889900_13_ITEM1A_P3_S0	merger and divestiture activity among oil and natural gas producers.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P3_S1	In particular, our revenue, profitability and cash flows are highly dependent upon prevailing prices for oil and natural gas and expectations about future prices.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P4_S0	For many years, oil and natural gas prices and markets have been extremely volatile.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Prices are affected by factors such as:
889900_13_ITEM1A_P5_S0	the price and availability of alternative fuels.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P5_S1	All of these factors are beyond our control.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S0	During the second quarter of 2008, the quarterly average market price of natural gas (Henry Hub spot price as reported by the Energy Information Administration) was $11.74 per Mcf and the quarterly average market price of oil (WTI spot price as reported by the Energy Information Administration) was $123.95 per barrel.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S1	In the last half of 2008, commodity prices rapidly declined and averaged $6.60 per Mcf for natural gas and $58.35 per barrel for oil in the fourth quarter of 2008.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S2	In 2009, the price of natural gas declined further and averaged $4.06 per Mcf for the year.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Oil prices remained depressed during 2009 as well and averaged $61.65 per barrel for the year.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S4	These declines in the market prices of natural gas and oil caused our customers to significantly reduce their drilling activities beginning in the fourth quarter of 2008, and drilling activities remained low throughout 2009.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S5	Drilling activities increased in 2010 as did the prices for oil and natural gas.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S6	The increased drilling activity was largely attributable to increased development of unconventional oil and natural gas reservoirs and an improvement in the price of oil which averaged $79.40 per barrel in 2010.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S7	Drilling for oil and liquids rich targets continued to increase in 2011 as oil averaged $94.86 per barrel for the year.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S8	Natural gas prices decreased in 2011 to an average of $4.00 per Mcf.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S9	The 2011 decrease in natural gas prices was most significant in the fourth quarter where the average price dropped to $3.32 per Mcf.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S10	This decrease continued into 2012 where natural gas prices fell below $2.00 per Mcf in April and averaged $2.75 per Mcf for the year, resulting in continued low levels of drilling activity for natural gas in 2012.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S11	The increase in drilling activity in oil rich basins absorbed some of the decrease in demand for natural gas drilling activities in 2012.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P6_S12	Our average number of rigs operating remains well below the number of our available rigs.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Construction of new land drilling rigs in the United States during the last decade has significantly contributed to excess capacity in total available drilling rigs.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P7_S1	As a result of decreased drilling activity and excess capacity, our average number of rigs operating has declined from historic highs.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P7_S2	We expect oil and natural gas prices to continue to be volatile and to affect our financial condition, operations and ability to access sources of capital.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P7_S3	Low market prices for oil and natural gas would likely result in lower demand for our drilling rigs and pressure pumping services and could adversely affect our operating results, financial condition and cash flows.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P7_S4	Even during periods of high prices for oil and natural gas, companies exploring for oil and natural gas may cancel or curtail programs, or reduce their levels of capital expenditures for exploration and production for a variety of reasons, which could reduce demand for our drilling rigs and pressure pumping services.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P7_S5	A General Excess of Operable Land Drilling Rigs, Increasing Rig Specialization and Excess Pressure Pumping Equipment May Adversely Affect Our Utilization and Profit Margins.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The North American oil and natural gas services industry has experienced downturns in demand during the last decade.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P8_S1	During these periods, there have been substantially more drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment available than necessary to meet demand.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P8_S2	As a result, drilling and pressure pumping contractors have had difficulty sustaining profit margins and, at times, have incurred losses during the downturn periods.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P9_S0	In addition, unconventional resource plays have substantially increased and some drilling rigs are not capable of drilling these wells efficiently.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P9_S1	Accordingly, the utilization of some older technology drilling rigs may be hampered by their lack of capability to successfully compete for this work.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P9_S2	Other ongoing factors which could continue to adversely affect utilization rates and pricing, even in an environment of high oil and natural gas prices and increased drilling activity, include:
889900_13_ITEM1A_P10_S0	construction of new technology drilling rigs.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Construction of new technology drilling rigs has increased in recent years.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P11_S1	The addition of new technology drilling rigs to the market, combined with a reduction in the drilling of vertical wells, has resulted in excess capacity of conventional drilling rigs.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Similarly, the substantial recent increase in unconventional resource plays has led to higher demand for pressure pumping services and there has been a significant increase in the construction of new pressure pumping equipment across the industry.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P11_S3	As a result of low natural gas prices and the construction of new equipment, there is currently an excess of pressure pumping equipment available.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P11_S4	In circumstances of excess capacity, providers of pressure pumping services have difficulty sustaining profit margins and may sustain losses during downturn periods.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P12_S0	We cannot predict the future level of demand for our contract drilling or pressure pumping services or future conditions in the oil and natural gas contract drilling or pressure pumping businesses.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Shortages of Drill Pipe, Replacement Parts, Other Equipment, Supplies and Materials Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P13_S0	During periods of increased demand for drilling and pressure pumping services, the industry has experienced shortages of drill pipe, replacement parts, other equipment, supplies and materials, including, in the case of our pressure pumping operations, proppants, acid, gel and water.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P13_S1	These shortages can cause the price of these items to increase significantly and require that orders for the items be placed well in advance of expected use.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P13_S2	In addition, any interruption in supply could result in significant delays in delivery of equipment and materials or prevent operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P13_S3	Interruptions may be caused by, among other reasons:
889900_13_ITEM1A_P14_S0	a shortage in the number of vendors able or willing to provide the necessary equipment, supplies and materials, including as a result of commitments of vendors to other customers or third parties.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P14_S1	These price increases, delays in delivery and interruptions in supply may require us to increase capital and repair expenditures and incur higher operating costs.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P14_S2	Severe shortages, delays in delivery and interruptions in supply could limit our ability to construct and operate our drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Fixed Term Contracts May in Certain Instances Be Terminated Without an Early Termination Payment.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P15_S1	Fixed term drilling contracts customarily provide for termination at the election of the customer, with an early termination payment to us if a contract is terminated prior to the expiration of the fixed term.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P15_S2	However, in certain circumstances, for example, destruction of a drilling rig that is not replaced within a specified period of time, our bankruptcy, or a breach of our contract obligations, no early termination payment may be paid to us.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P15_S3	Additionally, during depressed market conditions or otherwise, customers may be unable to satisfy their contractual obligations or may seek to terminate, renegotiate or fail to honor their contractual obligations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P15_S4	The failure to receive an early termination payment under a number of our fixed-term contracts could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P16_S0	The Oil Service Business Segments in Which We Operate Are Highly Competitive with Excess Capacity, which Adversely Affects Our Operating Results.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P16_S1	Our land drilling and pressure pumping businesses are highly competitive.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P16_S2	At times, available land drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment exceed the demand for such equipment.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P16_S3	This excess capacity has resulted in substantial competition for drilling and pressure pumping contracts.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P16_S4	The fact that drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment are mobile and can be moved from one market to another in response to market conditions heightens the competition in the industry.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P16_S5	We believe that price competition for drilling and pressure pumping contracts will continue to be intense due to the existence of available rigs and pressure pumping equipment.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P16_S6	As a result of competition, our utilization may decrease and/or we may be unable to maintain or increase prices for our services, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P16_S7	Labor Shortages and Rising Labor Costs Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P17_S0	During periods of increasing demand for contract drilling and pressure pumping services, the industry experiences shortages of qualified personnel.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P17_S1	During these periods, our ability to attract and retain sufficient qualified personnel to market and operate our drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment is adversely affected, which negatively impacts both our operations and profitability.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P17_S2	Operationally, it is more difficult to hire qualified personnel, which adversely affects our ability to mobilize inactive rigs and pressure pumping equipment in response to the increased demand for such services.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P17_S3	Additionally, wage rates for drilling and pressure pumping personnel are likely to increase during periods of increasing demand, resulting in higher operating costs.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P17_S4	The Loss of Large Customers Could Have a Material Adverse Effect on Our Financial Condition and Results of Operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P17_S5	In 2012, we received approximately 40% of our consolidated operating revenues from our ten largest customers and approximately 25% of our consolidated operating revenues from our five largest customers.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P17_S6	Although no single customer accounted for more than approximately seven percent of our consolidated operating revenue in 2012, the loss of one or more of our larger customers could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P17_S7	Growth Through the Building of New Rigs and Pressure Pumping Equipment and Rig and Other Acquisitions Are Not Assured.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P18_S0	We have increased our drilling rig fleet and pressure pumping horsepower in the past through mergers, acquisitions and new construction.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P18_S1	There can be no assurance that acquisition opportunities will be available in the future.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P18_S2	We are also likely to continue to face intense competition from other companies for available acquisition opportunities.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P18_S3	In addition, because improved technology has enhanced the ability to recover oil and natural gas, contract drillers may continue to build new, high technology rigs and providers of pressure pumping services may continue to build new, high horsepower equipment.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P18_S4	There can be no assurance that we will:
889900_13_ITEM1A_P19_S0	successfully improve our financial condition, results of operations, business or prospects as a result of any completed acquisition or the building of new drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We may incur substantial indebtedness to finance future acquisitions, build new drilling rigs or build new pressure pumping equipment and also may issue equity, convertible or debt securities in connection with any such acquisitions or building program.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Debt service requirements could represent a significant burden on our results of operations and financial condition, and the issuance of additional equity or convertible securities could be dilutive to existing stockholders.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Also, continued growth could strain our management, operations, employees and other resources.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S3	Our Operations Are Subject to a Number of Operational Risks, Including Environmental and Weather Risks, Which Could Expose Us to Significant Losses and Damage Claims.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S4	We Are Not Fully Insured Against All of These Risks and Our Contractual Indemnity Provisions May Not Fully Protect Us.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S5	Our operations are subject to many hazards inherent in the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses, including inclement weather, blowouts, well fires, loss of well control, pollution and reservoir damage.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S6	These hazards could cause personal injury or death, work stoppage, and serious damage to equipment and other property, as well as significant environmental and reservoir damages.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S7	These risks could expose us to substantial liability for personal injury, wrongful death, property damage, loss of oil and natural gas production, pollution and other environmental damages.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S8	We have indemnification agreements with many of our customers, and we also maintain liability and other forms of insurance.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S9	In general, our drilling and pressure pumping contracts typically contain provisions requiring our customers to indemnify us for, among other things, reservoir and certain pollution damage.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S10	Our right to indemnification may, however, be unenforceable or limited due to negligent or willful acts or omissions by us, our subcontractors and/or suppliers.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S11	Our customers may dispute, or be unable to meet, their indemnification obligations to us due to financial, legal or other reasons.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S12	Accordingly, we may be unable to transfer these risks to our customers by contract or indemnification agreements.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S13	Incurring a liability for which we are not fully indemnified or insured could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S14	We maintain insurance coverage of types and amounts that we believe to be customary in the industry, but we are not fully insured against all risks, either because insurance is not available or because of the high premium costs.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S15	The insurance coverage that we maintain includes insurance for fire, windstorm and other risks of physical loss to our rigs and certain other assets, employer s liability, automobile liability, commercial general liability insurance, workers compensation and insurance for other specific risks.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S16	We cannot assure, however, that any insurance obtained by us will be adequate to cover any losses or liabilities, or that this insurance will continue to be available or available on terms that are acceptable to us.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S17	While we carry insurance to cover physical damage to, or loss of, our drilling rigs and certain other assets, such insurance does not cover the full replacement cost of the rigs or other assets.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S18	We have also elected in some cases to accept a greater amount of risk through increased deductibles on certain insurance policies.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S19	For example, we generally maintain a $1.0 million per occurrence deductible on our workers compensation and equipment insurance coverage and a $2.0 million per occurrence self-insured retention on our general liability insurance coverage.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S20	We self-insure a number of other risks, including loss of earnings and business interruption, and do not carry a significant amount of insurance to cover risks of underground reservoir damage.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S21	Our insurance will not in all situations provide sufficient funds to protect us from all liabilities that could result from our operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S22	Our coverage includes aggregate policy limits and exclusions.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P20_S23	As a result, we retain the risk for any loss in excess of these limits or that is otherwise excluded from our coverage.

889900_13_ITEM1A_P21_S0	If a significant accident or other event occurs and is not fully covered by insurance or an enforceable or recoverable indemnity from a third party, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P21_S1	New Technologies, Process Improvements and Other Factors May Cause Our Drilling and Pressure Pumping Processes and Equipment to Become Less Competitive and Oil and Natural Gas Wells to be Drilled and Completed More Quickly, Resulting in an Adverse Effect on our Financial Condition and Results of Operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P21_S2	Changes in technology or improvements in competitors processes and equipment could make our processes and equipment less competitive or require significant capital expenditures to keep our processes and equipment competitive.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P21_S3	In addition, technological changes, process improvements and other factors that increase operational efficiencies could result in oil and natural gas wells being drilled and completed more quickly, which could reduce the number of revenue earning days.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P21_S4	Any such changes in technology could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P21_S5	Environmental Laws and Regulations, Including Violations Thereof Could Materially Adversely Affect Our Operating Results.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P21_S6	All of our operations and facilities are subject to numerous federal, state, foreign and local environmental laws, rules and regulations, including, without limitation, laws concerning the containment and disposal of hazardous substances, oil field waste and other waste materials, the use of underground storage tanks, and the use of underground injection wells.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P21_S7	The cost of compliance with these laws and regulations could be substantial.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P21_S8	A failure to comply with these requirements could expose us to substantial civil and criminal penalties.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P22_S0	In addition, environmental laws and regulations in the United States and Canada impose a variety of requirements on responsible parties related to the prevention of oil spills and liability for damages from such spills.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P22_S1	As an owner and operator of land-based drilling rigs and pressure pumping equipment, we may be deemed to be a responsible party under these laws and regulations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Changes in environmental laws and regulations occur frequently and such laws and regulations tend to become more stringent over time.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Stricter laws, regulations or enforcement policies could significantly increase compliance costs for us and our customers and have a material adverse effect on our operations or financial position.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P23_S2	For example, on August 16, 2012, the EPA issued final rules that establish new air emission control requirements for natural gas and NGL production, processing and transportation activities, including NSPS to address emissions of sulfur dioxide and volatile organic compounds and NESHAPS to address hazardous air pollutants frequently associated with gas production and processing activities.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P23_S3	Among other things, these final rules require the reduction of volatile organic compound emissions from natural gas wells through the use of reduced emission completions or green completions on all hydraulically fractured wells constructed or refractured after January 1, 2015.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P23_S4	In addition, gas wells are now required to use completion combustion device equipment (i.e., flaring) if emissions cannot be directed to a gathering line.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P23_S5	Further, the final rules under NESHAPS include maximum achievable control technology (MACT) standards for small glycol dehydrators that are located at major sources of hazardous air pollutants and modifications to the leak detection standards for valves.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P23_S6	These rules may require the implementation of new operating standards which may impact our business.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P23_S7	If these or other initiatives result in an increase in regulation, it could increase costs to us and our customers or reduce demand for our services, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P23_S8	Potential Legislation and Regulation Covering Hydraulic Fracturing Could Increase Our Costs and Limit or Delay Our Operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P23_S9	Members of the U.S. Congress and the EPA are reviewing more stringent regulation of hydraulic fracturing, a technology employed by our pressure pumping business, which involves the injection of water, sand and chemicals under pressure into rock formations to stimulate oil and natural gas production.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P24_S0	As part of their respective studies, the House Subcommittee on Energy and Environment and the EPA each sent requests to a number of companies, including our company, for information on their hydraulic fracturing practices.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P24_S1	We have responded to each of the inquiries.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P24_S2	In addition, legislation has been proposed in the U.S. Congress to amend the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act to require the disclosure of chemicals used by the oil and gas industry in the hydraulic fracturing process, which could make it easier for third parties opposing the hydraulic fracturing process to initiate legal proceedings based on allegations that specific chemicals used in the fracturing process are impairing ground water or causing other damage.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P24_S3	These bills, if adopted, could establish an additional level of regulation at the federal or state level that could limit or delay operational activities or increase operating costs and could result in additional regulatory burdens that could make it more difficult to perform or limit hydraulic fracturing and increase our costs of compliance and doing business.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P24_S4	Certain states where we operate, including Texas, have adopted or are considering similar disclosure legislation.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P24_S5	For example, Colorado, North Dakota, Montana, Texas, Louisiana, and Wyoming have adopted a variety of well construction, set back and disclosure regulations limiting how fracturing can be performed and requiring various degrees of chemical disclosure.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P24_S6	In addition, the EPA has asserted federal regulatory authority over hydraulic fracturing involving diesel additives under the Safe Drinking Water Act s Underground Injection Control Program and is developing guidance documents related to this newly asserted regulatory authority.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P24_S7	Additional regulation could increase the costs of conducting our business and could materially reduce our business opportunities and revenues if our customers decrease their levels of activity in response to such regulation.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P25_S0	A number of federal agencies are analyzing, or have been requested to review a variety of environmental issues associated with hydraulic fracturing.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P25_S1	For example, the EPA is conducting a study of the potential environmental effects of hydraulic fracturing on drinking water and groundwater.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P25_S2	The EPA released a progress report on December 21, 2012 outlining work currently underway and is expected to release results of the study in 2014.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P25_S3	In addition, the EPA announced on October 20, 2011 that it is launching a study of wastewater resulting from hydraulic fracturing activities and currently plans to propose pretreatment regulations by 2014.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P25_S4	These ongoing or proposed studies, depending on their course, and any meaningful results obtained, could spur initiatives to further regulate hydraulic fracturing under the Safe Drinking Water Act or other regulatory mechanism.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P25_S5	The adoption of any future federal or state laws or implementing regulations imposing reporting obligations on, or otherwise limiting, the hydraulic fracturing process could make it more difficult to perform hydraulic fracturing and could increase our costs of compliance and doing business and reduce demand for our services.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P25_S6	Regulation that significantly restricts or prohibits hydraulic fracturing could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P26_S0	We are aware of the increasing focus of local, state, national and international regulatory bodies on GHG emissions and climate change issues.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P26_S1	We are also aware of legislation proposed by United States lawmakers and the Canadian legislature to reduce GHG emissions, as well as GHG emissions regulations enacted by the EPA and the Canadian provinces of Alberta and British Columbia.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P27_S0	In December 2009, the EPA determined that emissions of carbon dioxide, methane and other GHG present a danger to public health and the environment because emissions of such gases are, according to the EPA, contributing to the warming of the earth s atmosphere and other climatic changes.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Based on its findings, the EPA has begun adopting and implementing regulations to restrict emissions of GHGs under existing provisions of the Federal Clean Air Act, including one regulation that requires a reduction in emissions of GHGs from motor vehicles and another that regulates emissions of GHGs from certain large sources.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P27_S2	In addition, the EPA published rules requiring reporting of GHG emissions from specified large GHG emission sources in the United States on an annual basis, which has been amended to include certain onshore and offshore oil and natural gas production facilities.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P27_S3	In addition, almost one-half of the states have already taken legal measures to reduce emissions of GHGs primarily through the planned development of GHG emission inventories and/or regional GHG cap and trade programs.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P28_S0	impact of GHG emissions and climate change on our operations and take appropriate actions, where necessary.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P28_S1	Any direct and indirect costs of meeting these requirements may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Because our business depends on the level of activity in the oil and natural gas industry, existing or future laws or regulations related to GHGs and climate change, including incentives to conserve energy or use alternative energy sources, could have a negative impact on our business if such laws or regulations reduce demand for oil and natural gas.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P28_S3	We Are Dependent Upon our Subsidiaries to Meet our Obligations Under our Long Term Debt We have borrowings outstanding under our senior notes, term loan facility and, from time to time, revolving credit facility.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P28_S4	These obligations are guaranteed by each of our existing subsidiaries other than immaterial subsidiaries.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P28_S5	Our ability to meet our interest and principal payment obligations depends in large part on dividends paid to us by our subsidiaries.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P28_S6	If our subsidiaries do not generate sufficient cash flows to pay us dividends, we may be unable to meet our interest and principal payment obligations.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P28_S7	Variable Rate Indebtedness Subjects Us to Interest Rate Risk, Which Could Cause Our Debt Service Obligations to Increase Significantly.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P29_S0	We have in place a committed senior unsecured credit facility that includes a revolving credit facility and a term loan facility.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Interest is paid on the outstanding principal amount of borrowings under the credit facility at a floating rate based on, at our election, LIBOR or a base rate.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P29_S2	The margin on LIBOR loans ranges from 2.25% to 3.25% and the margin on base rate loans ranges from 1.25% to 2.25%, based on our debt to capitalization ratio.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P29_S3	At December 31, 2012, the margin on LIBOR loans was 2.25% and the margin on base rate loans was 1.25%.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P29_S4	As of December 31, 2012, we had no borrowings outstanding under our revolving credit facility and $98.8 million outstanding under our term credit facility at an interest rate of 2.625%.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P29_S5	A one percent increase in the interest rate on the borrowings outstanding under our term credit facility as of December 31, 2012 would increase our annual cash interest expense by approximately $1.0 million.
889900_13_ITEM1A_P29_S6	Interest rates could rise for various reasons in the future and increase our total interest expense, depending upon the amounts borrowed.

889900_13_ITEM7_P0_S0	Management Overview We are a leading provider of services to the North American oil and natural gas industry.
889900_13_ITEM7_P0_S1	Our services primarily involve the drilling, on a contract basis, of land-based oil and natural gas wells and pressure pumping services.
889900_13_ITEM7_P0_S2	In addition to the aforementioned services, we also invest, on a non-operating working interest basis, in oil and natural gas properties.
889900_13_ITEM7_P0_S3	Prior to the sale of substantially all of the assets of our drilling and completion fluids business in January 2010, we provided drilling fluids, completion fluids and related services to oil and natural gas operators.
889900_13_ITEM7_P0_S4	Due to our exit from the drilling and completion fluids business in January 2010, we have presented the results of that business as discontinued operations in this Report.
889900_13_ITEM7_P0_S5	We acquired an electric wireline business on October 1, 2010 and sold the business on January 27, 2011.
889900_13_ITEM7_P0_S6	Due to our exit from the electric wireline business, we have presented the results of that business as discontinued operations in this Report.
889900_13_ITEM7_P1_S0	As of December 31, 2012, we had a drilling fleet that consisted of 314 marketable land-based drilling rigs.
889900_13_ITEM7_P2_S0	There continues to be uncertainty with respect to the global economic environment, crude oil prices are volatile and natural gas prices remain low.
889900_13_ITEM7_P2_S1	Activity in our drilling business decreased in the fourth quarter of 2012 compared to the fourth quarter of 2011.
889900_13_ITEM7_P2_S2	In the fourth quarter of 2012, our average number of rigs operating decreased to 206, as compared to an average of 232 drilling rigs operating during the same period in 2011.
889900_13_ITEM7_P2_S3	We have addressed our customers needs for drilling wells in the newer horizontal shale and other unconventional resource plays by expanding our areas of operation and improving the capabilities of our drilling fleet during the last several years.
889900_13_ITEM7_P2_S4	As of December 31, 2012, we have completed 113 new APEX rigs and made performance and safety improvements to existing high capacity rigs.
889900_13_ITEM7_P2_S5	We have plans to complete 13 additional new APEX rigs in 2013.
889900_13_ITEM7_P2_S6	In connection with the newer horizontal shale and other unconventional resource plays, we have added equipment to perform service intensive fracturing jobs.
889900_13_ITEM7_P2_S7	As of December 31, 2012, we had approximately 758,000 hydraulic horsepower in our pressure pumping fleet.
889900_13_ITEM7_P2_S8	This is a net increase of approximately 600,000 horsepower since the end of 2009.
889900_13_ITEM7_P3_S0	Low natural gas prices and the industry-wide addition of new pressure pumping equipment to the marketplace has led to an excess supply of pressure pumping equipment in North America.
889900_13_ITEM7_P4_S0	We maintain a backlog of commitments for contract drilling revenues under term contracts, which we define as contracts with a fixed term of six months or more.
889900_13_ITEM7_P4_S1	Our backlog as of December 31, 2012 was approximately $1.24 billion.
889900_13_ITEM7_P4_S2	We expect approximately $766 million of our backlog to be realized in 2013.
889900_13_ITEM7_P4_S3	We calculate our backlog by multiplying the day rate under our term drilling contracts by the number of days remaining under the contract.
889900_13_ITEM7_P4_S4	The calculation does not include any revenues related to other fees such as for mobilization, demobilization and customer reimbursables, nor does it include potential reductions in rates for unscheduled standby or during periods in which the rig is moving, on standby or incurring maintenance and repair time in excess of what is permitted under the drilling contract.
889900_13_ITEM7_P4_S5	In addition, generally our term drilling contracts are subject to termination by the customer on short notice and provide for an early termination payment to us in the event that the contract is terminated by the customer.
889900_13_ITEM7_P4_S6	See Item 1A. Risk Factors Fixed Term Contracts May in Certain Instances Be Terminated Without an Early Termination Payment.

889900_13_ITEM7_P7_S0	Our revenues, profitability and cash flows are highly dependent upon prevailing prices for oil and natural gas.
889900_13_ITEM7_P7_S1	During periods of improved commodity prices, the capital spending budgets of oil and natural gas operators tend to expand, which generally results in increased demand for our services.
889900_13_ITEM7_P7_S2	Conversely, in periods when these commodity prices deteriorate, the demand for our services generally weakens and we experience downward pressure on pricing for our services.
889900_13_ITEM7_P8_S0	After reaching a peak in June 2008, there was a significant decline in oil and natural gas prices and a substantial deterioration in the global economic environment.
889900_13_ITEM7_P8_S1	As part of this deterioration, there was substantial uncertainty in the capital markets and access to financing was reduced.
889900_13_ITEM7_P8_S2	Due to these conditions, our customers reduced or curtailed their drilling programs, which resulted in a decrease in demand for our services, as evidenced by the decline in our monthly average number of rigs operating from a high of 283 in October 2008 to a low of 60 in June 2009.
889900_13_ITEM7_P8_S3	Our monthly average number of rigs operating has subsequently increased from the mid-year low of 60 in 2009 to 233 in December 2011.
889900_13_ITEM7_P8_S4	In December 2012, our average number of rigs operating was 205.
