889900_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	Recent Developments Oil prices have significantly declined since the second half of 2014.
889900_16_ITEM7_P0_S1	The closing price of oil, which was as high as $105.68 per barrel during the third quarter of 2014, reached a low price for 2015 of $34.55 in December 2015 and reached a twelve-year low of $26.68 in January 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	severe decline in both contract drilling and pressure pumping activity levels.
889900_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	We do not expect this to change until commodity prices improve.
889900_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	Low commodity prices are negatively impacting spending by exploration and production companies.
889900_16_ITEM7_P2_S1	The impact of these spending reductions is evidenced by published rig counts, which in the United States decreased more than 60% during 2015 and is now almost 70% lower than the peak in 2014.
889900_16_ITEM7_P2_S2	Our rig count has also significantly declined.
889900_16_ITEM7_P2_S3	As of December 31, 2015, we had 80 drilling rigs operating in the United States, which was a decrease of 63% from the recent peak of 214 rigs in October 2014.
889900_16_ITEM7_P2_S4	Our operating rig count has continued to decline in 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P2_S5	On average, we operated 78 rigs in the United States during January 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P2_S6	Term contracts provided some support of our operating rig count during 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P2_S7	Based on contracts currently in place, we expect an average of 59 rigs operating under term contracts during the first quarter and an average of 46 rigs operating under term contracts during 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	Our pressure pumping business is continuing to experience the effects of reduced spending by customers and downward pressure on pricing.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S1	Due to market conditions, as of December 31, 2015, we had stacked approximately 38% of our fracturing horsepower.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S2	With the weakness in commodity prices since the beginning of 2016, we have seen a significant decrease in the amount of available work, and the profitability of available work has continued to deteriorate.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S3	In response, since the beginning of 2016, we have stacked approximately 140,000 fracturing horsepower.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S4	In total, we now have stacked slightly more than half of our fleet of more than 1 million hydraulic fracturing horsepower.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S5	In anticipation of this downturn, we began reducing our cost structure in the fourth quarter of 2014.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S6	In 2015, we continued to reduce our cost structure and, to date, we have reduced our drilling headcount at a rate generally proportionate with the reduction in our rig count.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S7	In 2015, we significantly reduced our pressure pumping headcount and obtained lower prices on many products and services that we use.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S8	We also reduced our capital expenditures in 2015, and we expect our capital expenditures for 2016 to primarily consist of maintenance capital, inspections and potential upgrades, as we do not expect to build any new rigs or purchase any new fracturing horsepower in 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S9	We plan to continue to adjust our cost structure in line with our level of operating activity.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S10	We expect that our term contract coverage in contract drilling and scalability with respect to labor and other operating costs in contract drilling and pressure pumping should position us to weather this downturn.
889900_16_ITEM7_P3_S11	In the event oil prices remain depressed for a sustained period, or decline further, we may experience further significant declines in both drilling activity and spot dayrate pricing and in pressure pumping activity, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889900_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	We are a leading provider of services to the North American oil and natural gas industry.
889900_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	Our services primarily involve the drilling, on a contract basis, of land-based oil and natural gas wells and pressure pumping services.
889900_16_ITEM7_P4_S2	In addition to these services, we also invest, on a non-operating working interest basis, in oil and natural gas properties.
889900_16_ITEM7_P4_S3	We operate land-based drilling rigs in oil and natural gas producing regions of the continental United States and western Canada, and we are pursuing contract drilling opportunities outside of North America.
889900_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	There continues to be uncertainty with respect to the global economic environment, and oil and natural gas prices are significantly depressed.

889900_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	In recent years, the industry-wide addition of new pressure pumping equipment to the marketplace and lower oil and natural gas prices have led to an excess supply of pressure pumping equipment in North America.
889900_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	We maintain a backlog of commitments for contract drilling revenues under term contracts, which we define as contracts with a fixed term of six months or more.
889900_16_ITEM7_P7_S1	Our contract drilling backlog as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 was $710 million and $1.5 billion, respectively.
889900_16_ITEM7_P7_S2	The decrease in backlog at December 31, 2015 from December 31, 2014, is primarily due to the revenue earned since December 31, 2014, including from the receipt of early termination payments, and the expiration and termination of term contracts.
889900_16_ITEM7_P7_S3	Approximately 40 percent of the total December 31, 2015 backlog is reasonably expected to remain after 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	calculate our backlog by multiplying the dayrate under our term drilling contracts by the number of days remaining under the contract.
889900_16_ITEM7_P8_S1	The calculation does not include any revenues related to other fees such as for mobilization, demobilization and customer reimbursables, nor does it include potential reductions in rates for unscheduled standby or during periods in which the ri g is moving or incurring maintenance and repair time in excess of what is permitted under the drilling contract.
889900_16_ITEM7_P8_S2	In addition, generally our term drilling contracts are subject to termination by the customer on short notice and provide for an early termina tion payment to us in the event that the contract is terminated by the customer.
889900_16_ITEM7_P8_S3	For contracts that we have received an early termination notice, our backlog calculation includes the early termination rate, instead of the dayrate , for the period we expect to receive the lower rate.
889900_16_ITEM7_P8_S4	See Item 1A. Risk Factors Our Current Backlog of Contract Drilling Revenue May Continue to Decline and May Not Ultimately Be Realized , as Fixed-Term Contracts May in Certain Instances Be Terminated Without an Early Termination Payment .

889900_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	In addition to established accounting policies, our consolidated financial statements are impacted by certain estimates and assumptions made by management.
889900_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	The following is a discussion of our critical accounting policies pertaining to property and equipment, goodwill, revenue recognition, the use of estimates and oil and natural gas properties.
889900_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	Property and equipment Property and equipment, including betterments which extend the useful life of the asset, are stated at cost.
889900_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	Maintenance and repairs are charged to expense when incurred.
889900_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	We provide for the depreciation of our property and equipment using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives.
889900_16_ITEM7_P14_S1	Our method of depreciation does not change when equipment becomes idle; we continue to depreciate idled equipment on a straight-line basis.
889900_16_ITEM7_P14_S2	No provision for salvage value is considered in determining depreciation of our property and equipment.
889900_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	We review our long-lived assets, including property and equipment, for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances ( triggering events ) indicate that the carrying values of certain assets may not be recovered over their estimated remaining useful lives.
889900_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	In connection with this review, assets are grouped at the lowest level at which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of other asset groupings.
889900_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	The cyclical nature of our industry has resulted in fluctuations in rig utilization over periods of time.
889900_16_ITEM7_P16_S1	Management believes that the contract drilling industry will continue to be cyclical and rig utilization will continue to fluctuate.
889900_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	Based on management s expectations of future trends, we estimate future cash flows over the life of the respective assets or asset groupings in our assessment of impairment.
889900_16_ITEM7_P17_S1	These estimates of cash flows are based on historical cyclical trends in the industry as well as management s expectations regarding the continuation of these trends in the future.
889900_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	Provisions for asset impairment are charged against income when estimated future cash flows, on an undiscounted basis, are less than the asset s net book value.
889900_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	Any provision for impairment is measured at fai r value.
889900_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	On a periodic basis, we evaluate our fleet of drilling rigs for marketability based on the condition of inactive rigs, expenditures that would be necessary to bring them to working condition and the expected demand for drilling services by rig type (such as drilling conventional, vertical wells versus drilling longer, horizontal wells using higher specification rigs).
889900_16_ITEM7_P19_S1	The components comprising rigs that will no longer be marketed are evaluated, and those components with continuing utility to our other marketed rigs are transferred to other rigs or to our yards to be used as spare equipment.
889900_16_ITEM7_P19_S2	The remaining components of these rigs will be retired.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	In 2015, we identified 24 mechanical rigs and 9 non-APEX electric rigs that would no longer be marketed.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S1	Also, we had 15 additional mechanical rigs that were not operating.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S2	Although these 15 rigs remain marketable, we have lower expectations with respect to utilization of these rigs due to the industry shift to higher specification drilling rigs.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S3	In 2015, we recorded a charge of $131 million related to the retirement of the 33 rigs, the 15 mechanical rigs that remain marketable but were not operating, and the write-down of excess spare rig components to their realizable values.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S4	In 2014, we identified 55 mechanical rigs that we determined would no longer be marketed, and we recorded a charge of $77.9 million related to the retirement of these mechanical rigs and the write-off of excess spare components for the reduced size of our mechanical fleet.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S5	In 2013, we identified 48 rigs that would no longer be marketed.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S6	Also, we had 55 additional mechanical rigs that were not operating.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S7	Although these 55 rigs remained marketable at the time, we had lower expectations with respect to utilization of these rigs due to the industry shift to electric powered drilling rigs.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S8	In 2013, we recorded a charge of $37.8 million related to the retirement of the 48 rigs and the 55 mechanical rigs that remained marketable but were not operating.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S9	We also periodically evaluate our pressure pumping assets, and in 2015, we recorded a charge of $22.0 million for the write-down of pressure pumping equipment and certain closed facilities.
889900_16_ITEM7_P20_S10	There were no similar charges in 2014 or 2013.
889900_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	We evaluate the recoverability of our long-lived assets whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that their carrying amounts may not be recoverable (a triggering event ).
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	During the first quarter of 2015, oil prices averaged $48.54 per barrel and reached a low of $43.39 per barrel in March 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S1	Oil prices improved during the second quarter of 2015 and averaged $57.85 per barrel.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S2	Although the price improvement was earlier than we projected, this improvement was generally consistent with our assumption at December 31, 2014 that oil prices would improve late in 2015 and continue to improve in 2016, resulting in improved activity levels for both the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S3	During the second quarter of 2015 as oil prices increased, we received requests from customers to reactivate drilling rigs to resume operations in the third quarter of 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S4	We believed this was an indication that future activity levels would be improving for both the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S5	During the third quarter of 2015, however, oil prices declined and averaged $46.42 per barrel and reached a new low for 2015 of $38.22 per barrel in August 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S6	With lower oil prices in August, we lowered our expectations with respect to future activity levels in both the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S7	In light of these revised expectations of the duration of the lower oil and natural gas commodity price environment and the related deterioration of the markets for contract drilling and pressure pumping services during the third quarter of 2015, we deemed it necessary to assess the recoverability of long-lived asset groups for both contract drilling and pressure pumping.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S8	We performed a Step 1 analysis as required by ASC 360-10-35 to assess the recoverability of long-lived assets within our contract drilling and pressure pumping segments.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S9	With respect to these assets, future cash flows were estimated over the expected remaining life of the assets, and we determined that, on an undiscounted basis, expected cash flows exceeded the carrying value of the long-lived assets, and no impairment was indicated.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S10	Expected cash flows, on an undiscounted basis, exceeded the carrying values of the long-lived assets within the contract drilling and pressure pumping segments by approximately 120% and 60%, respectively.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S11	Due to the continued deterioration of crude oil prices in the fourth quarter of 2015, we deemed it necessary to again assess the recoverability of long-lived assets groups for both contract drilling and pressure pumping.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S12	We performed a Step 1 analysis as required by ASC 360-10-35 to assess the recoverability of long-lived assets within our contract drilling and pressure pumping segments.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S13	With respect to these assets, future cash flows were estimated over the expected remaining life of the assets, and we determined that, on an undiscounted basis, expected cash flows exceeded the carrying value of the long-lived assets, and no impairment was indicated.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S14	Expected cash flows, on an undiscounted basis, exceeded the carrying values of the long-lived assets within the contract drilling and pressure pumping segments by approximately 120% and 100%, respectively.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S15	For both of the assessments performed in 2015, the expected cash flows for the contract drilling segment included the backlog of commitments for contract drilling revenues under term contracts, which was approximately $801 million and $710 million at September 30, 2015 and December 31, 2015, respectively.
889900_16_ITEM7_P22_S16	Rigs not under term contracts will be subject to pricing in the spot market.
889900_16_ITEM7_P23_S0	Utilization and rates for rigs in the spot market and for the pressure pumping segment were estimated based upon our historical experience in prior downturns.
889900_16_ITEM7_P23_S1	Also, the expected cash flows for the contract drilling and pressure pumping segments were based on the assumption that activity levels in both segments would begin to recover in the first quarter of 2017 in response to improved oil prices.
889900_16_ITEM7_P23_S2	While we believe these assumptions with respect to future pricing for oil and natural gas are reasonable, actual future prices may vary significantly from the ones that were assumed.
889900_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	The timeframe over which oil and natural gas prices will recover is highly uncertain.
889900_16_ITEM7_P24_S1	Potential events that could affect our assumptions regarding future prices and the timeframe for a recovery are affected by factors such as:
889900_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	regulations regarding the exploration, development, production and delivery of oil and natural gas.
889900_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	All of these factors are beyond our control.
889900_16_ITEM7_P26_S1	If the current lower oil and natural gas commodity price environment were to last into 2017 and beyond, our actual cash flows would likely be less than the expected cash flows used in these assessments and could result in impairment charges in the future and such impairment could be material.
889900_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	Goodwill Goodwill is considered to have an indefinite useful economic life and is not amortized.
889900_16_ITEM7_P27_S1	Goodwill is evaluated at least annually as of December 31, or when circumstances require, to determine if the fair value of recorded goodwill has decreased below its carrying value.
889900_16_ITEM7_P27_S2	For purposes of impairment testing, goodwill is evaluated at the reporting unit level.
889900_16_ITEM7_P27_S3	Our reporting units for impairment testing have been determined to be our operating segments.
889900_16_ITEM7_P27_S4	We first determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value after considering qualitative, market and other factors, and if it is, then goodwill impairment is determined using a two-step quantitative impairment test.
889900_16_ITEM7_P27_S5	From time to time, we may perform the first step of the quantitative testing for goodwill impairment in lieu of performing the qualitative assessment.
889900_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	The first step of the quantitative testing is to compare the fair value of an entity s reporting units to the respective carrying value of those reporting units.
889900_16_ITEM7_P28_S1	If the carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the quantitative testing is performed whereby the fair value of the reporting unit is allocated to its identifiable tangible and intangible assets and liabilities with any remaining fair value representing the fair value of goodwill.
889900_16_ITEM7_P28_S2	If this resulting fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value of goodwill, an impairment loss would be recognized in the amount of the shortfall.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	During the first quarter of 2015, oil prices averaged $48.54 per barrel and reached a low of $43.39 per barrel in March 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S1	Oil prices improved during the second quarter of 2015 and averaged $57.85 per barrel.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S2	Although the price improvement was earlier than we projected, this improvement was generally consistent with our assumption at December 31, 2014, that oil prices would improve in late 2015 and continue to improve in 2016, resulting in improved activity levels for both the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S3	During the second quarter of 2015 as oil prices increased, we received requests from customers to reactivate drilling rigs to resume operations in the third quarter of 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S4	We believed this was an indication that future activity levels would be improving for both the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S5	During the third quarter of 2015, however, oil prices declined and averaged $46.42 per barrel and reached a new low for 2015 of $38.22 per barrel in August 24, 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S6	With lower oil prices in August, we lowered our expectations with respect to future activity levels in both the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S7	In light of our revised expectations of the duration of the lower oil and natural gas commodity price environment and the related deterioration of the markets for contract drilling and pressure pumping services during the third quarter of 2015, we performed a quantitative impairment assessment of our goodwill as of September 30, 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S8	In completing the first step of the assessment, the fair value of each reporting unit was estimated using both the income and market valuation methods.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S9	The estimate of the fair value of each reporting unit required the use of significant unobservable inputs, representative of a Level 3 fair value measurement.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S10	The inputs included assumptions related to the future performance of our contract drilling and pressure pumping reporting units, such as future oil and natural gas prices and projected demand for our services, and assumptions related to discount rates, long-term growth rates and control premiums.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S11	Based on the results of the first step of the goodwill impairment test as of September 30, 2015, the fair value of the contract drilling reporting unit exceeded its carrying value by approximately 15%, and we concluded that no impairment was indicated in our contract drilling reporting unit; however, impairment was indicated in our pressure pumping reporting unit.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S12	In the three months ended September 30, 2015, we recognized an impairment charge of $125 million associated with the impairment of all of the goodwill of the pressure pumping reporting unit.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S13	We performed a quantitative impairment assessment of the goodwill of our contract drilling reporting unit as of December 31, 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S14	In completing the first step of the assessment, the fair value of the contract drilling reporting unit was estimated using both the income and market valuation methods.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S15	The estimate of the fair value of the reporting unit required the use of significant unobservable inputs, representative of a Level 3 fair value measurement.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S16	The inputs included assumptions related to the future performance of our contract drilling reporting unit, such as future oil and natural gas prices and projected demand for our services, and assumptions related to discount rates, long-term growth rates and control premiums.
889900_16_ITEM7_P29_S17	Based on the results of the first step of the quantitative impairment assessment of our goodwill, as of December 31, 2015, the fair value of our contract drilling reporting unit exceeded its carrying value by approximately 16%, and we concluded that no impairment was indicated in our contract drilling reporting unit.
889900_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	In connection with our annual goodwill impairment assessment as of December 31, 2014, we determined based on an assessment of qualitative factors that it was more likely than not that the fair values of our reporting units were greater than their carrying amounts and further testing was not necessary.
889900_16_ITEM7_P30_S1	In making this determination, we considered the continued demand experienced during 2014 for our services in the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses.
889900_16_ITEM7_P30_S2	We also considered the current and expected levels of commodity prices for oil and natural gas, which influence the overall level of business activity in these operating segments.
889900_16_ITEM7_P30_S3	Additionally, operating results for 2014 and forecasted operating results for 2015 were also taken into account.
889900_16_ITEM7_P30_S4	Our overall market capitalization and the large amount of calculated excess of the f air values of our reporting units over their carrying values from our 2013 quantitative Step 1 assessment of goodwill were also considered.
889900_16_ITEM7_P30_S5	We have undertaken extensive efforts in the past several years to upgrade our fleet of equipment and believe that we are well positioned from a competitive standpoint to satisfy demand for high technology drilling of unconventional horizontal wells, which should help mitigate decreases in demand for drilling conventional vertical wells.
889900_16_ITEM7_P30_S6	In the event that market conditions were to remain weak for a protracted period, we may be required to record an impairment of goodwill in our contract drilling reporting unit in the future, and such impairment could be material.
889900_16_ITEM7_P31_S0	Revenue recognition Revenues from daywork drilling and pressure pumping activities are recognized as services are performed.
889900_16_ITEM7_P31_S1	Expenditures reimbursed by customers are recognized as revenue and the related expenses are recognized as direct costs.
889900_16_ITEM7_P32_S0	All of the wells we drilled in 2015, 2014 and 2013 were drilled under daywork contracts.
889900_16_ITEM7_P33_S0	Use of estimates The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( U.S. GAAP ) requires management to make certain estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
889900_16_ITEM7_P33_S1	Actual results could differ from such estimates.
889900_16_ITEM7_P33_S2	Key estimates used by management include:
889900_16_ITEM7_P34_S0	reserves for self-insured levels of insurance coverage.
889900_16_ITEM7_P35_S0	Oil and natural gas properties Working interests in oil and natural gas properties are accounted for using the successful efforts method of accounting.
889900_16_ITEM7_P36_S0	Under the successful efforts method of accounting, exploration costs which result in the discovery of oil and natural gas reserves and all development costs are capitalized to the appropriate well.
889900_16_ITEM7_P36_S1	Exploration costs which do not result in discovering oil and natural gas reserves are charged to expense when such determination is made.
889900_16_ITEM7_P36_S2	Costs of exploratory wells are initially capitalized to wells-in-progress until the outcome of the drilling is known.
889900_16_ITEM7_P36_S3	We review wells-in-progress quarterly to determine whether sufficient progress is being made in assessing the reserves and economic viability of the respective projects.
889900_16_ITEM7_P36_S4	If no progress has been made in assessing the reserves and economic viability of a project after one year following the completion of drilling, we consider the well costs to be impaired and recognize the costs as expense.
889900_16_ITEM7_P36_S5	Geological and geophysical costs, including seismic costs and costs to carry and retain undeveloped properties, are charged to expense when incurred.
889900_16_ITEM7_P37_S0	The capitalized costs of both developmental and successful exploratory type wells, consisting of lease and well equipment and intangible development costs, are depreciated, depleted and amortized using the units-of-production method, based on engineering estimates of total proved developed oil and natural gas reserves for each respective field.
889900_16_ITEM7_P37_S1	Oil and natural gas leasehold acquisition costs are depreciated, depleted and amortized using the units-of-production method, based on engineering estimates of total proved oil and natural gas reserves for each respective field.
889900_16_ITEM7_P37_S2	We review our proved oil and natural gas properties for impairment whenever a triggering event occurs, such as downward revisions in reserve estimates or decreases in expected future oil and natural gas prices.
889900_16_ITEM7_P37_S3	Proved properties are grouped by field and undiscounted cash flow estimates are prepared based on our expectation of future pricing over the lives of the respective fields.
889900_16_ITEM7_P37_S4	These cash flow estimates are reviewed by an independent petroleum engineer.
889900_16_ITEM7_P38_S0	If the net book value of a field exceeds its undiscounted cash flow estimate, impairment expense is measured and recognized as the difference between net book value and fair value.
889900_16_ITEM7_P39_S0	The fair value estimates used in measuring impairment are based on internally developed unobservable inputs including reserve volumes and future production, pricing and operating costs (Level 3 inputs in the fair value hierarchy of fair value accounting).
889900_16_ITEM7_P39_S1	The expected future net cash flows are discounted using an annual rate of 10% to determine fair value.
889900_16_ITEM7_P40_S0	We review unproved oil and natural gas properties quarterly to assess potential impairment.
889900_16_ITEM7_P40_S1	Our impairment assessment is made on a lease-by-lease basis and considers factors such as our intent to drill, lease terms and abandonment of an area.
889900_16_ITEM7_P41_S0	If an unproved property is determined to be impaired, the related property costs are expensed.
889900_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	approximately $ 10.7 million, $ 20.9 million and $ 4.0 million for the years ended Dece mber 31, 201 5 , 201 4 and 201 3 , respectively, and is included in depreciation, depletion, amortization and impairment in the consolidated statements of operations.
889900_16_ITEM7_P42_S1	For additional information on our accounting policies, see Note 1 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included as a part of Item 8 of this Report.

889900_16_ITEM7_P43_S1	We believe our current liquidity, together with cash expected to be generated from operations, should provide us with sufficient ability to fund our current plans to maintain and make improvements to our existing equipment, service our debt and pay cash dividends.
889900_16_ITEM7_P43_S2	If under current market conditions we desire to pursue opportunities for growth that require capital, we believe we would likely require additional debt or equity financing.
889900_16_ITEM7_P43_S3	However, there can be no assurance that such capital will be available on reasonable terms, if at all.

889900_16_ITEM7_P51_S0	2012 Credit Agreement On September 27, 2012, we entered into a credit agreement (the Credit Agreement ).
889900_16_ITEM7_P51_S1	The Credit Agreement is a committed senior unsecured credit facility that includes a revolving credit facility and a term loan facility.
889900_16_ITEM7_P51_S2	The Credit Agreement replaced a previous senior unsecured revolving credit facility.
889900_16_ITEM7_P51_S3	The revolving credit facility permits aggregate borrowings of up to $500 million outstanding at any time.
889900_16_ITEM7_P51_S4	The revolving credit facility contains a letter of credit facility that is limited to $150 million and a swing line facility that is limited to $40 million, in each case outstanding at any time.
889900_16_ITEM7_P51_S5	The term loan facility provides for a loan of $100 million, which was drawn on December 24, 2012.
889900_16_ITEM7_P51_S6	The term loan facility is payable in quarterly principal installments which commenced December 27, 2012.
889900_16_ITEM7_P51_S7	The installment amounts vary from 1.25% of the original principal amount for each of the first four quarterly installments, 2.50% of the original principal amount for each of the subsequent eight quarterly installments, 5.00% of the original principal amount for the subsequent four quarterly installments and 13.75% of the original principal amount for the final four quarterly installments.
889900_16_ITEM7_P52_S0	Subject to customary conditions, we may request that the lenders aggregate commitments with respect to the revolving credit facility and/or the term loan facility be increased by up to $100 million, not to exceed total commitments of $700 million.
889900_16_ITEM7_P52_S1	The maturity date under the Credit Agreement is September 27, 2017 for both the revolving facility and the term facility.
889900_16_ITEM7_P53_S0	Loans under the Credit Agreement bear interest by reference, at our election, to the LIBOR rate or base rate, provided, that swing line loans bear interest by reference only to the base rate.
889900_16_ITEM7_P53_S1	The applicable margin on LIBOR rate loans varies from 2.25% to 3.25% and the applicable margin on base rate loans varies from 1.25% to 2.25%, in each case determined based upon our debt to capitalization ratio.
889900_16_ITEM7_P53_S2	As of December 31, 2015, the applicable margin on LIBOR rate loans was 2.25% and the applicable margin on base rate loans was 1.25%.
889900_16_ITEM7_P53_S3	Based on our debt to capitalization ratio at September 30, 2015, the applicable margin on LIBOR rate loans is 2.25% and the applicable margin on base rate loans is 1.25% as of January 1, 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P53_S4	Based on our debt to capitalization ratio at December 31, 2015, the applicable margin on LIBOR rate loans will be 2.75% and the applicable margin on base rate loans will be 1.75% as of April 1, 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P53_S5	A letter of credit fee is payable by us equal to the applicable margin for LIBOR rate loans times the amount available to be drawn under outstanding letters of credit.
889900_16_ITEM7_P53_S6	The commitment fee rate payable to the lenders for the unused portion of the credit facility is 0.50%.
889900_16_ITEM7_P54_S0	Each of our domestic subsidiaries will unconditionally guarantee all existing and future indebtedness and liabilities of the other guarantors and us arising under the Credit Agreement, other than (a) Ambar Lone Star Fluid Services LLC, (b) domestic subsidiaries that directly or indirectly have no material assets other than equity interests in, or capitalization indebtedness owed by, foreign subsidiaries, and (c) any subsidiary having total assets of less than $1 million.
889900_16_ITEM7_P54_S1	Such guarantees also cover our obligations and those of any of our subsidiaries arising under any interest rate swap contract with any person while such person is a lender or an affiliate of a lender under the Credit Agreement.
889900_16_ITEM7_P55_S0	The Credit Agreement requires compliance with two financial covenants.
889900_16_ITEM7_P55_S1	We must not permit our debt to capitalization ratio to exceed 45%.
889900_16_ITEM7_P56_S0	day of t he most recently ended fiscal quarter.
889900_16_ITEM7_P56_S1	We also must not permit the interest coverage ratio as of the last day of a fiscal quarter to be less than 3.00 to 1.00.

889900_16_ITEM7_P115_S0	Adjusted EBITDA Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization ( Adjusted EBITDA ) is not defined by U.S. GAAP.
889900_16_ITEM7_P115_S1	We define Adjusted EBITDA as net income (loss) plus net interest expense, income tax expense (benefit) and depreciation, depletion, amortization and impairment expense.
889900_16_ITEM7_P115_S2	We present Adjusted EBITDA (a non-U.S. GAAP measure) because we believe it provides to both management and investors additional information with respect to both the performance of our fundamental business activities and our ability to meet our capital expenditures and working capital requirements.
889900_16_ITEM7_P115_S3	Adjusted EBITDA should not be construed as an alternative to the U.S. GAAP measures of net income (loss) or operating cash flow.
889900_16_ITEM7_P116_S0	The effective tax rate is a result of a federal rate of 35.0% adjusted as follows:
889900_16_ITEM7_P117_S0	The Domestic Production Activities Deduction (IRC section 199 deduction) was enacted as part of the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 (as revised by the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008) and allows a deduction of 9% in 2010 and thereafter on the lesser of qualified production activities income or taxable income.
889900_16_ITEM7_P117_S1	The permanent differences for 2013 include a deduction of $10.0 million as we fully utilized our remaining net operating loss carryforwards.
889900_16_ITEM7_P117_S2	The permanent differences for 2014 include a deduction of $8.8 million.
889900_16_ITEM7_P117_S3	The permanent differences for 2015 do not include any deduction as it is limited to taxable income, and we did not have taxable income in 2015 as a result of our election to utilize bonus depreciation.
889900_16_ITEM7_P117_S4	The 2015 other differences include a 1.0% reduction related to the reconciliation of the deferred tax liability associated with the conversion of our Canadian operations to a controlled foreign corporation.
889900_16_ITEM7_P117_S5	The impact to the deferred tax liability from the conversion is being amortized over the weighted average remaining useful life of the Canadian assets.
889900_16_ITEM7_P117_S6	The 2015 other differences also include a 0.7% reduction for the lost benefit of the 2014 IRC section 199 deduction of $8.8 million as a result of our adoption of the final tangible property regulations with the filing of the 2014 tax return.
889900_16_ITEM7_P118_S0	We record deferred federal income taxes based primarily on the temporary differences between the book and tax bases of our assets and liabilities.
889900_16_ITEM7_P118_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the year in which those temporary differences are expected to be settled.
889900_16_ITEM7_P118_S2	As a result of fully recognizing the benefit of our deferred income taxes, we incur deferred income tax expense as these benefits are utilized.
889900_16_ITEM7_P118_S3	We recognized a deferred tax benefit of approximately $100 million in 2015 and deferred tax expense of approximately $44 million in 2014 and $51 million in 2013.
889900_16_ITEM7_P119_S0	On January 1, 2010, we converted our Canadian operations from a Canadian branch to a controlled foreign corporation for federal income tax purposes.
889900_16_ITEM7_P120_S0	increase to deferred i ncome tax expense over the weighted average remaining useful life of the Canadian assets.
889900_16_ITEM7_P120_S1	This will be fully amortized by December 31, 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P121_S0	As a result of the above conversion, our Canadian assets are no longer directly subject to United States taxation, provided that the related unremitted earnings are permanently reinvested in Canada.
889900_16_ITEM7_P121_S1	Effective January 1, 2010, we have elected to permanently reinvest these unremitted earnings in Canada, and intend to do so for the foreseeable future.
889900_16_ITEM7_P121_S2	As a result, no deferred United States federal or state income taxes have been provided on such unremitted foreign earnings, which totaled approximately $28.4 million as of December 31, 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P121_S3	The unrecognized deferred tax liability associated with these earnings was approximately $3.8 million, net of available foreign tax credits.
889900_16_ITEM7_P121_S4	This liability would be recognized if we received a dividend of the unremitted earnings.
889900_16_ITEM7_P122_S0	Volatility of Oil and Natural Gas Prices and its Impact on Operations and Financial Condition Our revenue, profitability and cash flows are highly dependent upon prevailing prices for oil and natural gas and expectations about future prices.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S0	For many years, oil and natural gas prices and markets have been extremely volatile.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S1	Prices are affected by many factors beyond our control.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S2	Please see Risk Factors We are Dependent on the Oil and Gas Industry and Market Prices for Oil and Natural Gas.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S3	Declines in Customers Operating and Capital Expenditures and in Oil and Natural Gas Prices May Adversely Affect Our Operating Results in Item 1A of this Report.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S4	Oil prices have significantly declined since the second half of 2014.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S5	The closing price of oil, which was as high as $105.68 per barrel during the third quarter of 2014, reached a low price for 2015 of $34.55 in December 2015 and reached a twelve-year low of $26.68 in January 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S6	As a result of the prolonged decline in oil prices, our industry continues to experience a severe decline in both contract drilling and pressure pumping activity levels.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S7	We do not expect this to change until commodity prices improve.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S8	We expect oil and natural gas prices to continue to be volatile and to affect our financial condition, operations and ability to access sources of capital.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S9	Higher oil and natural gas prices do not necessarily result in increased activity because demand for our services is generally driven by our customers expectations of future oil and natural gas prices.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S10	A continued decline in demand for oil and natural gas or prolonged low oil or natural gas prices would likely result in further reduced capital expenditures by our customers and decreased demand for our drilling rigs and pressure pumping services, which could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and cash flows.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S11	Impact of Inflation Inflation has not had a significant impact on our operations during the three years ended December 31, 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P123_S12	We believe that inflation will not have a significant near-term impact on our financial position.
889900_16_ITEM7_P124_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued an accounting standards update to provide guidance on the recognition of revenue from customers.
889900_16_ITEM7_P124_S1	Under this guidance, an entity will recognize revenue when it transfers promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects what it expects in exchange for the goods or services.
889900_16_ITEM7_P124_S2	This guidance also requires more detailed disclosures to enable users of the financial statements to understand the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty, if any, of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers.
889900_16_ITEM7_P124_S3	The requirements in this update are effective during interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P124_S4	We are currently evaluating the impact this guidance will have on our consolidated financial statements.
889900_16_ITEM7_P125_S0	In June 2014, the FASB issued an accounting standards update to provide guidance on the accounting for share-based payments when the terms of an award provide that a performance target could be achieved after the requisite service period.
889900_16_ITEM7_P125_S1	The guidance requires that a performance target that affects vesting and that could be achieved after the requisite service period is treated as a performance condition.
889900_16_ITEM7_P125_S2	The requirements in this update are effective during interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P125_S3	The adoption of this update is not expected to have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.
889900_16_ITEM7_P126_S0	In April 2015, the FASB issued an accounting standards update to provide guidance for the presentation of debt issuance costs.
889900_16_ITEM7_P126_S1	Under this guidance, debt issuance costs shall be presented in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of the related debt and shall not be classified as a deferred charge.
889900_16_ITEM7_P126_S2	Amortization of debt issuance costs shall continue to be reported as interest expense.
889900_16_ITEM7_P126_S3	The requirements in this update are effective during interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2015.
889900_16_ITEM7_P126_S4	The adoption of this update is not expected to have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.
889900_16_ITEM7_P127_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued an accounting standards update to provide guidance for the presentation of deferred tax liabilities and assets.
889900_16_ITEM7_P127_S1	Under this guidance, for a particular tax-paying component of an entity and within a particular tax jurisdiction, all deferred tax liabilities and assets, as well as any related valuation allowance, shall be offset and presented as a single noncurrent amount.
889900_16_ITEM7_P127_S2	The requirements in this update are effective during interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7_P127_S3	The adoption of this update is not expected to have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Under the Credit Agreement, interest is paid on the outstanding principal amount of borrowings at a floating rate based on, at our election, LIBOR or a base rate.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The margin on LIBOR loans ranges from 2.25% to 3.25% and the margin on base rate loans ranges from 1.25% to 2.25%, based on our debt to capitalization ratio.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S2	At December 31, 2015, the margin on LIBOR loans was 2.25% and the margin on base rate loans was 1.25%.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Based on our debt to capitalization ratio at September 30, 2015, the applicable margin on LIBOR loans is 2.25% and the applicable margin on base rate loans is 1.25% as of January 1, 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S4	Based on our debt to capitalization ratio at December 31, 2015, the applicable margin on LIBOR loans will be 2.75% and the applicable margin on base rate loans will be 1.75% as of April 1, 2016.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S5	As of December 31, 2015, we had no amounts outstanding under our revolving credit facility and $70.0 million outstanding under our term loan facility at an interest rate of 2.875%.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S6	The interest rate on the borrowings outstanding under the Credit Agreement is variable and adjusts at each interest payment date based on our election of LIBOR or the base rate.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S7	A one percent increase in the interest rate on the borrowings outstanding under our term credit facility as of December 31, 2015 would increase our annual cash interest expense by approximately $632,000.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S8	Loans under the 2015 Term Loan Agreement bear interest, at our election, at the per annum rate of LIBOR plus 3.25% or base rate plus 2.25%.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S9	As of December 31, 2015, we had $185 million principal amount outstanding under the 2015 Term Loan Agreement at an interest rate of 3.875%.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P0_S10	A one percent increase in the interest rate on the borrowings outstanding under 2015 Term Loan Agreement as of December 31, 2015 would increase our annual cash interest expense by approximately $1.8 million.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Under the Reimbursement Agreement, we will reimburse the issuing bank on demand for any amounts that it has disbursed under any letters of credit.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P1_S1	We are obligated to pay to the issuing bank interest on all amounts not paid by us on the date of demand or when otherwise due at the LIBOR rate plus 2.25% per annum.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P1_S2	As of December 31, 2015, no amounts had been disbursed under any letters of credit.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P2_S0	We conduct a portion of our business in Canadian dollars through our Canadian land-based drilling operations.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The exchange rate between Canadian dollars and U.S. dollars has fluctuated during the last several years.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P3_S1	If the value of the Canadian dollar against the U.S. dollar weakens, revenues and earnings of our Canadian operations will be reduced and the value of our Canadian net assets will decline when they are translated to U.S. dollars.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P3_S2	This currency risk is not material to our results of operations or financial condition.
889900_16_ITEM7A_P3_S3	The carrying values of cash and cash equivalents, trade receivables and accounts payable approximate fair value due to the short-term maturity of these items.

889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S0	R eport of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm To the Board of Directors and Stockholders of Patterson-UTI Energy, Inc.: In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements listed in the accompanying index present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Patterson-UTI Energy, Inc. and its subsidiaries (the Company ) at December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2015 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S1	In addition, in our opinion, the financial statement schedule listed in the index appearing under Item 15(a)(2) presents fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein when read in conjunction with the related consolidated financial statements.
889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S2	Also in our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ).
889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S3	The Company s management is responsible for these financial statements and financial statement schedule, for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in Management s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting appearing under Item 9A.
889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S4	Our responsibility is to express opinions on these financial statements, on the financial statement schedule, and on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our integrated audits.
889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S5	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S6	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement and whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S7	Our audits of the financial statements included examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S8	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S9	Our audits also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
889900_16_ITEM15_P42_S10	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinions.
889900_16_ITEM15_P43_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
889900_16_ITEM15_P43_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
889900_16_ITEM15_P43_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
889900_16_ITEM15_P43_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.

889900_16_ITEM15_P49_S0	Description of Business and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies A description of the business and basis of presentation follows: Description of business Patterson-UTI Energy, Inc., through its wholly-owned subsidiaries (collectively referred to herein as Patterson-UTI or the Company ), provides onshore contract drilling services to major, independent and other oil and natural gas operators in the continental United States and western Canada.
889900_16_ITEM15_P49_S1	The Company provides pressure pumping services to major, independent and other oil and natural gas operators primarily in Texas and the Appalachian region.
889900_16_ITEM15_P49_S2	The Company also invests in oil and natural gas properties on a non-operating working interest basis.
889900_16_ITEM15_P49_S3	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Patterson-UTI and its wholly-owned subsidiaries.
889900_16_ITEM15_P49_S4	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
889900_16_ITEM15_P49_S5	Except for wholly-owned subsidiaries, the Company has no controlling financial interests in any other entity which would require consolidation.
889900_16_ITEM15_P50_S0	The U.S. dollar is the functional currency for all of the Company s operations except for its Canadian operations, which use the Canadian dollar as its functional currency.
889900_16_ITEM15_P51_S0	The effects of exchange rate changes are reflected in accumulated other comprehensive income, which is a separate component of stockholders equity.
889900_16_ITEM15_P52_S0	A summary of the significant accounting policies follows: Management estimates The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
889900_16_ITEM15_P52_S1	Actual results could differ from such estimates.
889900_16_ITEM15_P53_S0	Revenue recognition Revenues from daywork drilling and pressure pumping activities are recognized as services are performed.
889900_16_ITEM15_P53_S1	Expenditures reimbursed by customers are recognized as revenue and the related expenses are recognized as direct costs.
889900_16_ITEM15_P54_S0	All of the wells the Company drilled in 2015, 2014 and 2013 were drilled under daywork contracts.
889900_16_ITEM15_P55_S0	Accounts receivable Trade accounts receivable are recorded at the invoiced amount.
889900_16_ITEM15_P56_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts represents the Company s estimate of the amount of probable credit losses existing in the Company s accounts receivable.
889900_16_ITEM15_P56_S1	The Company reviews the adequacy of its allowance for doubtful accounts at least quarterly.
889900_16_ITEM15_P56_S2	Significant individual accounts receivable balances and balances which have been outstanding greater than 90 days are reviewed individually for collectability.
889900_16_ITEM15_P57_S0	Account balances, when determined to be uncollectable, are charged against the allowance.
889900_16_ITEM15_P58_S0	Inventories Inventories consist primarily of sand and other products to be used in conjunction with the Company s pressure pumping activities.
889900_16_ITEM15_P58_S1	The inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market, determined under the average cost method.
889900_16_ITEM15_P58_S2	Property and equipment Property and equipment is carried at cost less accumulated depreciation.
889900_16_ITEM15_P58_S3	Depreciation is provided on the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives.
889900_16_ITEM15_P58_S4	The method of depreciation does not change whenever equipment becomes idle.
889900_16_ITEM15_P58_S5	The estimated useful lives, in years, are shown below:
889900_16_ITEM15_P59_S0	Long-lived assets, including property and equipment, are evaluated for impairment when certain triggering events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying values may not be recoverable over their estimated remaining useful life.
889900_16_ITEM15_P60_S0	Oil and natural gas properties Working interests in oil and natural gas properties are accounted for using the successful efforts method of accounting.
889900_16_ITEM15_P61_S0	Under the successful efforts method of accounting, exploration costs which result in the discovery of oil and natural gas reserves and all development costs are capitalized to the appropriate well.
889900_16_ITEM15_P61_S1	Exploration costs which do not result in discovering oil and natural gas reserves are charged to expense when such determination is made.
889900_16_ITEM15_P61_S2	Costs of exploratory wells are initially capitalized to wells-in-progress until the outcome of the drilling is known.
889900_16_ITEM15_P61_S3	The Company reviews wells-in-progress quarterly to determine whether sufficient progress is being made in assessing the reserves and economic viability of the respective projects.
889900_16_ITEM15_P62_S0	drilling, the Company considers the well costs to be impaired and recognizes the costs as expense.
889900_16_ITEM15_P62_S1	Geologi cal and geophysical costs, including seismic costs, and costs to carry and retain undeveloped properties are charged to expense when incurred.
889900_16_ITEM15_P63_S0	The capitalized costs of both developmental and successful exploratory type wells, consisting of lease and well equipment and intangible development costs, are depreciated, depleted and amortized using the units-of-production method, based on engineering estimates of total proved developed oil and natural gas reserves for each respective field.
889900_16_ITEM15_P63_S1	Oil and natural gas leasehold acquisition costs are depreciated, depleted and amortized using the units-of-production method, based on engineering estimates of total proved oil and natural gas reserves for each respective field.
889900_16_ITEM15_P63_S2	The Company reviews its proved oil and natural gas properties for impairment whenever a triggering event occurs, such as downward revisions in reserve estimates or decreases in expected future oil and natural gas prices.
889900_16_ITEM15_P63_S3	Proved properties are grouped by field and undiscounted cash flow estimates are prepared based on management s expectation of future pricing over the lives of the respective fields.
889900_16_ITEM15_P63_S4	These cash flow estimates are reviewed by an independent petroleum engineer.
889900_16_ITEM15_P64_S0	If the net book value of a field exceeds its undiscounted cash flow estimate, impairment expense is measured and recognized as the difference between net book value and fair value.
889900_16_ITEM15_P65_S0	The fair value estimates used in measuring impairment are based on internally developed unobservable inputs including reserve volumes and future production, pricing and operating costs (Level 3 inputs in the fair value hierarchy of fair value accounting).
889900_16_ITEM15_P65_S1	The expected future net cash flows are discounted using an annual rate of 10% to determine fair value.
889900_16_ITEM15_P66_S0	The Company reviews unproved oil and natural gas properties quarterly to assess potential impairment.
889900_16_ITEM15_P66_S1	The Company s impairment assessment is made on a lease-by-lease basis and considers factors such as management s intent to drill, lease terms and abandonment of an area.
889900_16_ITEM15_P66_S2	If an unproved property is determined to be impaired, the related property costs are expensed.
889900_16_ITEM15_P67_S0	Goodwill Goodwill is considered to have an indefinite useful economic life and is not amortized.
889900_16_ITEM15_P67_S1	The Company assesses impairment of its goodwill at least annually as of December 31, or on an interim basis if events or circumstances indicate that the fair value of goodwill may have decreased below its carrying value.
889900_16_ITEM15_P68_S0	Maintenance and repairs Maintenance and repairs are charged to expense when incurred.
889900_16_ITEM15_P68_S1	Renewals and betterments which extend the life or improve existing property and equipment are capitalized.
889900_16_ITEM15_P68_S2	Disposals Upon disposition of property and equipment, the cost and related accumulated depreciation are removed and any resulting gain or loss is reflected in the consolidated statement of operations.
889900_16_ITEM15_P68_S3	Net income (loss) per common share The Company provides a dual presentation of its net income (loss) per common share in its consolidated statements of operations: Basic net income (loss) per common share ( Basic EPS ) and diluted net income (loss) per common share ( Diluted EPS ).
889900_16_ITEM15_P68_S4	Basic EPS excludes dilution and is computed by first allocating earnings between common stockholders and holders of non-vested shares of restricted stock.
889900_16_ITEM15_P68_S5	Basic EPS is then determined by dividing the earnings attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period, excluding non-vested shares of restricted stock.
889900_16_ITEM15_P68_S6	Diluted EPS is based on the weighted average number of common shares outstanding plus the dilutive effect of potential common shares, including stock options, non-vested shares of restricted stock and restricted stock units.
889900_16_ITEM15_P68_S7	The dilutive effect of stock options and restricted stock units is determined using the treasury stock method.
889900_16_ITEM15_P68_S8	The dilutive effect of non-vested shares of restricted stock is based on the more dilutive of the treasury stock method or the two-class method, assuming a reallocation of undistributed earnings to common stockholders after considering the dilutive effect of potential common shares other than non-vested shares of restricted stock.
889900_16_ITEM15_P69_S0	The following table presents information necessary to calculate net income (loss) per share for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, as well as potentially dilutive securities excluded from the weighted average numbe r of diluted common shares outstanding because their inclusion would have been anti-dilutive (in thousands, except per share amounts):
889900_16_ITEM15_P70_S0	Income taxes The asset and liability method is used in accounting for income taxes.
889900_16_ITEM15_P70_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for operating loss and tax credit carryforwards and for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases.
889900_16_ITEM15_P70_S2	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the year in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
889900_16_ITEM15_P70_S3	The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in the results of operations in the period that includes the enactment date.
889900_16_ITEM15_P70_S4	If applicable, a valuation allowance is recorded to reduce the carrying amounts of deferred tax assets unless it is more likely than not that such assets will be realized.
889900_16_ITEM15_P71_S0	The Company s policy is to account for interest and penalties with respect to income taxes as operating expenses.
889900_16_ITEM15_P72_S0	Stock-based compensation The Company recognizes the cost of share-based payments under the fair-value-based method.
889900_16_ITEM15_P72_S1	Under this method, compensation cost related to share-based payments is measured based on the estimated fair value of the awards at the date of grant, net of estimated forfeitures.
889900_16_ITEM15_P72_S2	This expense is recognized over the expected life of the awards (See Note 10).
889900_16_ITEM15_P73_S0	Statement of cash flows For purposes of reporting cash flows, cash and cash equivalents include cash on deposit and money market funds.
889900_16_ITEM15_P74_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued an accounting standards update to provide guidance on the recognition of revenue from customers.
889900_16_ITEM15_P74_S1	Under this guidance, an entity will recognize revenue when it transfers promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects what it expects in exchange for the goods or services.
889900_16_ITEM15_P74_S2	This guidance also requires more detailed disclosures to enable users of the financial statements to understand the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty, if any, of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers.
889900_16_ITEM15_P74_S3	The requirements in this update are effective during interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
889900_16_ITEM15_P74_S4	The Company is currently evaluating the impact this guidance will have on its consolidated financial statements.
889900_16_ITEM15_P74_S5	In June 2014, the FASB issued an accounting standards update to provide guidance on the accounting for share-based payments when the terms of an award provide that a performance target could be achieved after the requisite service period.
889900_16_ITEM15_P74_S6	The guidance requires that a performance target that affects vesting and that could be achieved after the requisite service period is treated as a performance condition.
889900_16_ITEM15_P74_S7	The requirements in this update are effective during interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2015.
889900_16_ITEM15_P74_S8	The adoption of this update is not expected to have a material impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
889900_16_ITEM15_P75_S0	In April 2015, the FASB issued an accounting standards update to provide guidance for the presentation of debt issuance costs.
889900_16_ITEM15_P75_S1	Under this guidance, debt issua nce costs shall be presented in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of the related debt and shall not be classified as a deferred charge.
889900_16_ITEM15_P75_S2	Amortization of debt issuance costs shall continue to be reported as interest expense.
889900_16_ITEM15_P75_S3	T he requirements in this update are effective during interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2015.
889900_16_ITEM15_P75_S4	The adoption of this update is not expected to have a material impact on the Company s con solidated financial statements.
889900_16_ITEM15_P76_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued an accounting standards update to provide guidance for the presentation of deferred tax liabilities and assets.
889900_16_ITEM15_P76_S1	Under this guidance, for a particular tax-paying component of an entity and within a particular tax jurisdiction, all deferred tax liabilities and assets, as well as any related valuation allowance, shall be offset and presented as a single noncurrent amount.
889900_16_ITEM15_P76_S2	The requirements in this update are effective during interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
889900_16_ITEM15_P76_S3	The adoption of this update is not expected to have a material impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.

889900_16_ITEM15_P81_S0	On a periodic basis, the Company evaluates its fleet of drilling rigs for marketability based on the condition of inactive rigs, expenditures that would be necessary to bring them to working condition and the expected demand for drilling services by rig type (such as drilling conventional, vertical wells versus drilling longer, horizontal wells using higher specification rigs).
889900_16_ITEM15_P81_S1	The components comprising rigs that will no longer be marketed are evaluated, and those components with continuing utility to the Company s other marketed rigs are transferred to other rigs or to the Company s yards to be used as spare equipment.
889900_16_ITEM15_P81_S2	The remaining components of these rigs will be retired.
889900_16_ITEM15_P82_S0	In 2015, the Company identified 24 mechanical rigs and 9 non-APEX electric rigs that would no longer be marketed.
889900_16_ITEM15_P82_S1	Also, the Company had 15 additional mechanical rigs that were not operating.
889900_16_ITEM15_P82_S2	Although these 15 rigs remain marketable, the Company has lower expectations with respect to utilization of these rigs due to the industry shift to higher specification drilling rigs.
889900_16_ITEM15_P82_S3	In 2015, the Company recorded a charge of $131 million related to the retirement of the 33 rigs, the 15 mechanical rigs that remain marketable but were not operating, and the write-down of excess spare rig components to their realizable values.
889900_16_ITEM15_P82_S4	In 2014, the Company identified 55 mechanical rigs that it determined would no longer be marketed, and the Company recorded a charge of $77.9 million related to the retirement of these mechanical rigs and the write-off of excess spare components for the reduced size of the Company s mechanical fleet.
889900_16_ITEM15_P83_S0	In 2013, the Company identified 48 rigs that would no longer be marketed.
889900_16_ITEM15_P83_S1	Also, the Company had 55 additional mechanical rigs that were not operating.
889900_16_ITEM15_P83_S2	Although these 55 rigs remained marketable at the time, the Company had lower expectations with respect to utilization of these rigs due to the industry shift to electric powered drilling rigs.
889900_16_ITEM15_P83_S3	In 2013, the Company recorded a charge of $37.8 million related to the retirement of the 48 rigs and the 55 mechanical rigs that remained marketable but were not operating.
889900_16_ITEM15_P83_S4	The Company also periodically evaluates its pressure pumping assets, and in 2015, the Company recorded a charge of $22.0 million for the write-down of pressure pumping equipment and certain closed facilities.
889900_16_ITEM15_P83_S5	There were no similar charges in 2014 or 2013.
889900_16_ITEM15_P84_S0	The Company evaluates the recoverability of its long-lived assets whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that their carrying amounts may not be recoverable (a triggering event ).
889900_16_ITEM15_P85_S0	During the first quarter of 2015, oil prices averaged $48.54 per barrel and reached a low of $43.39 per barrel in March 2015.
889900_16_ITEM15_P85_S1	Oil prices improved during the second quarter of 2015 and averaged $57.85 per barrel.
889900_16_ITEM15_P85_S2	Although the price improvement was earlier than the Company projected, this improvement was generally consistent with the Company s assumption at December 31, 2014 that oil prices would improve late in 2015 and continue to improve in 2016, resulting in improved activity levels for both the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses.
889900_16_ITEM15_P85_S3	During the second quarter of 2015 as oil prices increased, the Company received requests from customers to reactivate drilling rigs to resume operations in the third quarter of 2015.
889900_16_ITEM15_P85_S4	The Company believed this was an indication that future activity levels would be improving for both the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses.
889900_16_ITEM15_P85_S5	During the third quarter of 2015, however, oil prices declined and averaged $46.42 per barrel and reached a new low for 2015 of $38.22 per barrel in August 2015.
889900_16_ITEM15_P85_S6	With lower oil prices in August, the Company lowered its expectations with respect to future activity levels in both the contract drilling and pressure pumping businesses.
889900_16_ITEM15_P85_S7	In light of these revised expectations of the duration of the lower oil and natural gas commodity price environment and the related deterioration of the markets for contract drilling and pressure pumping services during the third quarter of 2015, management deemed it necessary to assess the recoverability of long-lived asset groups for both contract drilling and pressure pumping.
889900_16_ITEM15_P86_S0	The Company performed a Step 1 analysis as required by ASC 360-10-35 to assess the recoverability of long-lived assets within its contract drilling and pressure pumping segments.
889900_16_ITEM15_P86_S1	With respect to these assets, future cash flows were estimated over the expected remaining life of the assets, and the Company determined that, on an undiscounted basis, expected cash flows exceeded the carrying value of the long-lived assets, and no impairment was indicated.
889900_16_ITEM15_P86_S2	Expected cash flows, on an undiscounted basis, exceeded the carrying values of the long-lived assets within the contract drilling and pressure pumping segments by approximately 120% and 60%, respectively.
889900_16_ITEM15_P86_S3	Due to the continued deterioration of crude oil prices in the fourth quarter of 2015, management deemed it necessary to again assess the recoverability of long-lived assets groups for both contract drilling and pressure pumping.
889900_16_ITEM15_P86_S4	The Company performed a Step 1 analysis as required by ASC 360-10-35 to assess the recoverability of long-lived assets within its contract drilling and pressure pumping segments.
889900_16_ITEM15_P86_S5	With respect to these assets, future cash flows were estimated over the expected remaining life of the assets, and the Company determined that, on an undiscounted basis, expected cash flows exceeded the carrying value of the long-lived assets, and no impairment was indicated.
889900_16_ITEM15_P86_S6	Expected cash flows, on an undiscounted basis, exceeded the carrying values of the long-lived assets within the contract drilling and pressure pumping segments by approximately 120% and 100%, respectively.
889900_16_ITEM15_P86_S7	For both of the assessments performed in 2015, the expected cash flows for the contract drilling segment included the backlog of commitments for contract drilling revenues under term contracts, which was approximately $801 million and $710 million at September 30, 2015 and December 31, 2015, respectively .
889900_16_ITEM15_P86_S8	Rigs not under term contracts will be subject to pricing in the spot market.
889900_16_ITEM15_P87_S0	Company s historical experience in prior downturns.
889900_16_ITEM15_P87_S1	Also, the expected cash flows for the contract drilling and pressure pumping segments were based on the assumption that activity levels in both segments would begin to recover in the first quarter of 2017 in respo nse to improved oil prices.
889900_16_ITEM15_P87_S2	While management believes these assumptions with respect to future pricing for oil and natural gas are reasonable, actual future prices may vary significantly from the ones that were assumed.
889900_16_ITEM15_P88_S0	The timeframe over which oil and natural gas prices will recover is highly uncertain.
889900_16_ITEM15_P88_S1	Potential events that could affect the Company s assumptions regarding future prices and the timeframe for a recovery are affected by factors such as:
889900_16_ITEM15_P89_S0	regulations regarding the exploration, development, production and delivery of oil and natural gas.
889900_16_ITEM15_P90_S0	All of these factors are beyond the Company s control.
889900_16_ITEM15_P90_S1	If the current lower oil and natural gas commodity price environment were to last into 2017 and beyond, the Company s actual cash flows would likely be less than the expected cash flows used in these assessments and could result in impairment charges in the future and such impairment could be material.

889900_16_ITEM15_P92_S0	Goodwill and Intangible Assets Goodwill Goodwill by operating segment as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 and changes for the years then ended are as follows (in thousands):
889900_16_ITEM15_P93_S0	There were no accumulated impairment losses related to goodwill in the contract drilling operating segment as of December 31, 2015 or 2014.
889900_16_ITEM15_P94_S0	Goodwill is evaluated at least annually as of December 31, or when circumstances require, to determine if the fair value of recorded goodwill has decreased below its carrying value.
889900_16_ITEM15_P94_S1	For purposes of impairment testing, goodwill is evaluated at the reporting unit level.
889900_16_ITEM15_P94_S2	The Company s reporting units for impairment testing have been determined to be its operating segments.
889900_16_ITEM15_P94_S3	The Company first determines whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value after considering qualitative, market and other factors, and if it is, then goodwill impairment is determined using a two-step quantitative impairment test.
889900_16_ITEM15_P94_S4	From time to time, the Company may perform the first step of the quantitative testing for goodwill impairment in lieu of performing the qualitative assessment.
889900_16_ITEM15_P95_S0	The first step of the quantitative testing is to compare the fair value of an entity s reporting units to the respective carrying value of those reporting units.
889900_16_ITEM15_P95_S1	If the carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the quantitative testing is performed whereby the fair value of the reporting unit is allocated to its identifiable tangible and intangible assets and liabilities with any remaining fair value representing the fair value of goodwill.
889900_16_ITEM15_P95_S2	If this resulting fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value of goodwill, an impairment loss would be recognized in the amount of the shortfall.
